revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Earth observation]]
Technology | operator = [[National Aerospace Development Administration|NADA]] | COSPAR_ID = 2016-009A | SATCAT = 41332 | mission_duration = 4 years (planned) | spacecraft_bus = | manufacturer = | dry_mass = 150 to 200 Kilograms{{cite web|title=Status of North Korean Satellite unknown after prolonged Radio Silence, Reports of Tumbling|url=http://spaceflight101.com/status-of-north-korean-satellite-unknown-after-prolonged-radio-silence-reports-of-tumbling/|website=Spaceflight101}} | launch_mass = | power = | launch_date = 7 February 2016, 00:30 UTC | launch_rocket = [[Unha|Kwangmyongsong]] | launch_site = [[Sohae Satellite Launching Station|Sohae Space Center]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | last_contact = | decay_date = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[Sun-synchronous orbit]] | orbit_regime = [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|465|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|502|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 97.5 degrees | orbit_semimajor = | orbit_eccentricity = | orbit_period = 94 minutes, 24 seconds | apsis = gee }} {{Infobox Korean name |hangul=광명성―4호 |hanja=光明星4號 |rr=Gwangmyeongseong-4 ho |mr=Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4 |context=north }} [[File:North Korean missile launches over Japan.svg|thumb|right|Satellite launches of North Korea. ①: [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-1]] ②: [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2]] ③: [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3]] ④: Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4]] '''Kwangmyongsong-4''' ({{Language with name/for|ko|Korean|Bright Star-4 or Lodestar-4}}) or '''KMS-4'''{{Cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=41332|title=Technical details for satellite KMS-4|website=N2YO.com - Real Time Satellite Tracking and Predictions|access-date=2018-10-09}} is an [[earth observation satellite]] launched by [[North Korea]] on 7 February 2016. The launch happened after North Korea [[January 2016 North Korean nuclear test|conducted a nuclear test]] on 6 January and as the [[United Nations Security Council]] was deciding on sanctions to be placed on the country following the nuclear test. The launch was also timed to celebrate the 74th birthday of the late leader [[Kim Jong-il]] on February 16. ==Pre-launch== On 2 February 2016, North Korea sent a notification to the [[International Maritime Organization]] stating that the country was going to launch a [[Kwangmyongsong program|Kwangmyongsong earth observation satellite]] with a launch window of 8–25 February between 22:30 UTC and 03:30 UTC given. The notification also included the drop zones for the first stage, the payload fairing and the second stage of the rocket, which was similar to the areas designated for the launch of [[Kwangmyongsong-3 Unit 2]].{{Cite web|title = Launch notification reveals rocket drop zones - North Korea Tech|url = https://www.northkoreatech.org/2016/02/03/launch-notification-reveals-rocket-drop-zones/|website = northkoreatech.org|access-date = 2016-02-08}} On 6 February 2016, North Korea sent another notification to the International Maritime Organization stating that the launch window had been changed to 7–14 February.{{Cite web|title = All systems go? DPRK brings forward launch window - North Korea Tech|url = https://www.northkoreatech.org/2016/02/07/all-systems-go-dprk-brings-forward-launch-window/|website = northkoreatech.org|access-date = 2016-02-08}} ==Launch== [[File:Kim Jong-un's order on launching Kwangmyongsong-4.jpg|thumb|Order on launching the satellite, signed by [[Kim Jong-un]]]] The satellite was launched on 7 February 2016 at 00:30 UTC into roughly a [[sun-synchronous orbit]] well suited for an [[earth observation satellite]],{{cite news |url=http://38north.org/2016/02/jschilling020816/ |title=North Korea's Space Launch: An Initial Assessment |author=John Schilling |publisher=U.S.-Korea Institute, Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies |work=38 North |date=9 February 2016 |accessdate=10 February 2016}} using an [[Unha]] launch vehicle{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/northkorea-satellite-idUKKCN0VG04Z |title=North Korean rocket puts object into space, angers neighbours, U.S. |author1=Ju-min Park |author2=Jack Kim |publisher=Reuters |date=7 February 2016 |accessdate=7 February 2016}} at [[Sohae Satellite Launching Station|Sohae Space Centre]] in [[Cholsan County]], [[North Phyongan Province]].{{Cite web|title = DPRK announces successful launch of Kwangmyongsong-4 satellite - CCTV News - CCTV.com English|url = http://english.cntv.cn/2016/02/07/ARTI98lx135UGjmMIJwXw1FB160207.shtml|website = english.cntv.cn|access-date = 2016-02-07}} Regarded as sending a message to both neighboring [[China]] as well as the [[United States]], the launch also took place on the eve of the [[Chinese New Year]] and the [[Super Bowl]] in [[United States]].[https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2016/02/north-koreas-successful-satellite-in-orbit-but-tumbling-and-useless/ North Korea’s 'successful' satellite in orbit] - ARS Technica, 2/10/2016, 12:41 AM It was initially claimed by U.S. officials that the satellite was "tumbling in orbit" and that no signals had yet been detected being transmitted from it.[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/north-korea-satellite-tumbling-in-orbit-u-s-officials-say/ North Korean satellite "tumbling in orbit," U.S. officials say] - CBSnews.com, 8 February 2016 However, it was later reported the tumbling had been brought under control and the orbit stabilized.{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-satellite-orbit-idUSKCN0VI1XN |title=North Korea satellite in stable orbit but not seen transmitting: U.S. sources |author1=Andrea Shalal |author2=David Brunnstrom |publisher=Reuters |date=10 February 2016 |accessdate=10 February 2016}} This indicates that the satellite has established communication with North Korea. The head of the [[U.S. Army Space and Missile Defense Command]] stated that Kwangmyongsong-4 was almost twice as large as Kwangmyongsong-3, and South Korean officials estimated the mass as {{convert|200|kg}}.{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-northkorea-satelitte-missiledefense-idUKKCN0VJ2PF |title=North Korea satellite not transmitting, but rocket payload a concern - U.S. |author=David Brunnstrom |publisher=Reuters |date=11 February 2016 |accessdate=15 February 2016}} Russian news agency [[TASS]] reported on February 22nd statement by Colonel Andrei Kalyuta of Russia's National Space Monitoring Center, based on orbit of the satellite its in line with declared purpose, activity of satellite and equipment were confirmed.{{Cite news|url=http://special.tass.ru/politika/2688450|title=ТАСС|access-date=2018-10-09|language=ru}} Satellite tracker and astronomer for [[Leiden Observatory]] has Marco Langbroek captured images of the satellite on February 28th, based on long exposure images the satellite is either not tumbling or is in a very slow tumble . Evident by stability of brightness that is reflection of the sun when satellite passes over the camera.{{Cite news|url=https://www.northkoreatech.org/2016/03/03/north-koreas-satellite-caught-on-camera/|title=North Korea's new satellite caught on camera|date=2016-03-03|work=North Korea Tech - 노스코리아테크|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight101.com/north-korean-satellite-stabilizes-in-orbit-reports-of-satellite-operation-remain-unconfirmed/|title=North Korean Satellite stabilizes in Orbit, Reports of Satellite Operation remain unconfirmed – Spaceflight101|website=spaceflight101.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-09}} Bob Christy of Zarya website shared results of observing orbital periods of the satellite, it indicates satellite is not tumbling and is under control as controlled reduction in altitude of the orbit was detected.{{Cite web|url=http://www.zarya.info/Diaries/NKorea/Kwangmyongsong4ndot2.php|title=Kwangmyongsong 4 Orbital Decay|website=www.zarya.info|access-date=2018-10-09}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nknews.org/2016/04/north-korea-claims-satellite-is-transmitting-images/|title=North Korea claims satellite is transmitting images {{!}} NK News - North Korea News|date=2016-04-07|work=NK News - North Korea News|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-US}} [[North Korea Tech]](affiliate of [[38 North]]) reported on findings made by Langbroek and Christy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.northkoreatech.org/2016/03/03/north-koreas-satellite-caught-on-camera/|title=North Korea's new satellite caught on camera|date=2016-03-03|work=North Korea Tech - 노스코리아테크|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-US}} [[Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics]] Jonathan Mcdowell concludes satellite is at least partially operational based on visual information and observation of satellites gravity boom being deployed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nknews.org/2016/03/n-korean-satellite-sending-songs-other-signals-to-earth-media/|title=N.Korean satellite sending songs, other signals to earth: media {{!}} NK News - North Korea News|date=2016-03-10|work=NK News - North Korea News|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-US}} ==Post-Launch== North Korea registered the satellite with the [[United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs]] on May 9.{{cite web|title=North Korea Registers Satellite with UN|url=https://www.nknews.org/2016/05/north-korea-registers-satellite-with-un/|first=Leo|last=Byrne|date=27 May 2016|access-date=27 May 2016|publisher=NK News}} In addition to claiming North Korea was planning a moon mission, Hyon Kwang-il, director of the scientific research department at NADA, said the satellite had completed 2,513 orbits and had transmitted 700 photographic images in the day following its launch.{{cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/ap-exclusive-north-korea-hopes-to-plant-flag-on-the-moon/ar-BBvePu4?li=BBnbcA1 |title=AP Exclusive: North Korea hopes to plant flag on the moon |publisher=Associated Press |date=4 August 2016 |accessdate=4 August 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820032940/http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/ap-exclusive-north-korea-hopes-to-plant-flag-on-the-moon/ar-BBvePu4?li=BBnbcA1 |archivedate= 20 August 2016 |df= }} The satellite passes over North Korea four times a day and continues to transmit data.{{Update after|2017|02}} However, international experts, such as astrophysicist [[Jonathan McDowell]], have not confirmed any transmissions from the satellite. In May 2017 North Korea has released satellite images of [[Terminal High Altitude Area Defense|THAAD]] site in Seongju county, South Korea.{{Cite web|url=http://m.yna.co.kr/mob2/en/contents_en.jsp?cid=AEN20170510009000315&site=0400000000&mobile|title=Yonhapnews Agency - Mobile|website=m.yna.co.kr|language=en|access-date=2018-10-09}} ==Reactions== [[File:北ミサイル発射 号外 2016 読売 (24587661389).jpg|thumb|''[[Yomiuri Shimbun]]'' newspaper extra informing Japanese readers about the launch]] The North Korean government organized a fireworks display on February 7, 2016 in commemoration of the launch.{{cite news|last1=Ellis|first1=Ralph|last2=Kwon|first2=K.J.|last3=Ap|first3=Tiffany|last4=Hume|first4=Tim|title=North Korea celebrates satellite launch with fireworks display|publisher=CNN|date=8 February 2016}} South Korea, Japan, the United States and other countries have accused North Korea of testing a ballistic missile (Unha is the satellite launch version of [[Taepodong-2]]) capable of hitting the United States.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/02/06/asia/north-korea-rocket-launch-window/|title=U.S., other nations condemn North Korean rocket launch - CNN.com|author=Ralph Ellis, K.J. Kwon and Tiffany Ap, CNN|date=6 February 2016|work=CNN|accessdate=7 February 2016}} However, some experts believe North Korea is still a decade away from having the capability to successfully deliver a nuclear weapon by means of an [[intercontinental ballistic missile]] (ICBM), and the launch shows slow, but continuous, progress.{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-northkorea-satellite-technology-idUKKCN0VI0M7 |title=North Korea turns to 'old workhorse' rocket to repeat past success |author1=Jack Kim |author2=David Brunnstrom |publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2016 |accessdate=9 February 2016}} The director of the U.S. [[Missile Defense Agency]] stated the launch was not a test of an intercontinental ballistic missile. The launch was strongly condemned by the [[United Nations Security Council|UN Security Council]].{{Cite web|title = UN Security Council vows new sanctions after N Korea's rocket launch|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-35518058|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-02-07}}{{Cite web|title = U.N. Security Council condemns North Korea launch - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2016/02/07/asia/north-korea-rocket-launch-window/index.html|website = CNN|access-date = 2016-02-07}}{{Cite news|title = North Korea rocket launch: UN security council condemns latest violation|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/07/north-korea-launches-long-range-rocket-it-claims-is-carrying-a-satellite|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 2016-02-07|access-date = 2016-02-07|issn = 0261-3077|language = en-GB|first = Justin McCurry Damien|last = Gayle|last2 = agencies}} It prompted [[South Korea]] and the [[United States]] to announce that they would explore the possibility of deploying [[Terminal High Altitude Area Defense|Terminal High Altitude Area Defence]] (THAAD),{{Cite web|title = China worried over US-South Korea plans to deploy THAAD missile system - The Economic Times|url = http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/china-worried-over-us-south-korea-plans-to-deploy-thaad-missile-system/articleshow/50892130.cms|website = The Economic Times|access-date = 2016-02-07}}{{Cite web|title = Korea says THAAD 'helpful' to security|url = http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/01/205_196787.html|website = koreatimes|access-date = 2016-02-07}} an advanced missile defence system, in South Korea, which is strongly opposed by [[China]]{{Cite web|title = North Korean rocket puts object into space, angers neighbours, U.S.|url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-northkorea-satellite-idUKKCN0VG00L|website = Reuters UK|access-date = 2016-02-07|language = en-GB}} and [[Russia]].{{Cite web|title = Russia: Korean THAAD Deployment Is a Security Threat|url = http://thediplomat.com/2015/04/russia-korean-thaad-deployment-is-a-security-threat/|website = The Diplomat|access-date = 2016-02-08|first = John Power, The|last = Diplomat}} ==See also== {{Portal|North Korea|Spaceflight}} * [[2016 in spaceflight]] * [[List of North Korean missile tests|List of North Korean Missile Tests]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist |2}} ==External links== * [http://n2yo.com/?s=41332 Live time satellite tracking] {{North Korean Space Program}} {{Orbital launches in 2016}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kwangmyongsong-4}} [[Category:Earth observation satellites]] [[Category:Space program of North Korea]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2016]] [[Category:2016 in North Korea]]

revision.text:
{{short description|Huge regional accumulation of igneous rocks}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} [[Image:Flood_Basalt_Map.jpg|thumb|300px|Only a few of the largest large igneous provinces appear (coloured dark purple) on this geological map, which depicts crustal geologic provinces as seen in [[seismic refraction]] data.]]
A '''large igneous province''' (LIP) is an extremely large accumulation of [[igneous rock]]s, including intrusive (sills) and extrusive (lava flows, tephra deposits), arising when magma travels through the crust towards the surface. The formation of LIPs is variously attributed to [[mantle plume]]s or to processes associated with divergent [[plate tectonic]]s.<ref name=Foulger>{{cite book |title= Plates vs. Plumes: A Geological Controversy |author= Foulger, G.R. |authorlink= Gillian Foulger |url= http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1405161485.html |year= 2010 |isbn= 978-1-4051-6148-0 |publisher= Wiley-Blackwell}}</ref> The formation of some of the LIPs the past 500 million years coincide in time with mass extinctions and rapid climatic changes, which has led to numerous hypotheses about the causal relationships. LIPs are fundamentally different from any other currently active volcanoes or volcanic systems.
== Definition == In 1992 researchers first used the term ''large igneous province'' to describe very large accumulations—areas greater than 100,000 square kilometers (approximately the area of Iceland)—of [[mafic]] igneous rocks that were erupted or emplaced at depth within an extremely short [[geological time]] interval: a few million years or less.<ref name=Coffin>{{cite book |last=Coffin |first=M |last2=Eldholm |first2=O |ref=CITEREFCoffinEldholm1992 |year=1992 |chapter=Volcanism and continental break-up: a global compilation of large igneous provinces |editors=Storey, B.C., Alabaster, T., [[Robert John Pankhurst|Pankhurst, R.J.]] |title=Magmatism and the Causes of Continental Breakup |publisher=Geological Society of London |series=Special Publications |place=London |volume=68 |pages=17–30 |doi=10.1144/GSL.SP.1992.068.01.02 |bibcode = 1992GSLSP..68...17C }}</ref> Mafic, basalt sea floors and other geological products of 'normal' plate tectonics were not included in the definition.<ref name=Bryan>{{Cite web |last=Bryan |first=Scott |last2=Ernst |first2=Richard |year = 2007 | doi = 10.1016/j.earscirev.2007.08.008|url=http://www.mantleplumes.org/LIPClass2.html |title=Proposed Revision to Large Igneous Province Classification |bibcode=2008ESRv...86..175B }}</ref>
=== Types === The definition of ''LIP'' has been expanded and refined, and is still a work in progress. ''LIP'' is now frequently also used to describe voluminous areas of, not just mafic, but all types of igneous rocks. Sub-categorization of LIPs into ''large volcanic provinces'' (LVP) and ''large plutonic provinces'' (LPP), and including rocks produced by normal plate tectonic processes, has been proposed but are not generally accepted.<ref name="Sheth">{{Cite journal|last=Sheth|first=Hetu C.|year=2007|title='Large Igneous Provinces (LIPs)': Definition, recommended terminology, and a hierarchical classification|url=http://www.mantleplumes.org/WebDocuments/sheth2007-esr.pdf|journal=Earth-Science Reviews|volume=85|issue=3–4|pages=117–124|bibcode=2007ESRv...85..117S|doi=10.1016/j.earscirev.2007.07.005}}</ref>
Some LIPs are geographically intact, such the basaltic [[Deccan Traps]] in India, while others have been fragmented and separated by plate movements, like the [[Central Atlantic Magmatic Province]] (CAMP)—parts of which are found in Brazil, eastern North America, and north-western Africa<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Svensen|first=H. H.|last2=Torsvik|first2=T. H.|last3=Callegaro|first3=S.|last4=Augland|first4=L.|last5=Heimdal|first5=T. H.|last6=Jerram|first6=D. A.|last7=Planke|first7=S.|last8=Pereira|first8=E.|date=2017-08-30|title=Gondwana Large Igneous Provinces: plate reconstructions, volcanic basins and sill volumes|url=http://mr.crossref.org/iPage?doi=10.1144%2FSP463.7|journal=Geological Society, London, Special Publications|volume=463|issue=1|pages=17–40|doi=10.1144/sp463.7|issn=0305-8719}}</ref>.
==Motivations for study of LIPs== [[File:Flood Basalt Map.jpg|thumb|400px|right|Map showing the recognized continental large igneous provinces.]] Large igneous provinces (LIPs) are created during short-lived igneous events resulting in relatively rapid and high-volume accumulations of volcanic and intrusive igneous rock. These events warrant study because:
* The possible links to mass extinctions and global environmental and climatic changes. [[Michael Rampino]] and [[Richard Stothers]] (1988) cited eleven distinct flood-basalt episodes - occurring in the past 250 million years - which created volcanic provinces and oceanic plateaus and coincided with [[mass extinctions]].<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Michael R. Rampino & Richard B. Stothers|year=1988|title=Flood Basalt Volcanism During the Past 250 Million Years|url=http://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/docs/1988/1988_Rampino_Stothers_1.pdf|journal=Science|volume=241|issue=4866|pages=663–668|bibcode=1988Sci...241..663R|doi=10.1126/science.241.4866.663|pmid=17839077}}{{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> This theme has developed into a broad field of research, bridging geoscience disciplines such as biostratigraphy, volcanology, metamorphic petrology, and Earth System Modelling.
*The study of LIPs has economic implications. Some workers associate them with trapped hydrocarbons.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} They are associated with economic concentrations of copper–nickel and iron.<ref name=Eremin>N. I. Eremin; Platform Magmatism: Geology and Minerageny; ISSN 1075-7015, Geology of Ore Deposits, 2010, Vol. 52, No. 1, pp. 77–80. © Pleiades Publishing, Ltd., 2010. {{doi|10.1134/S1075701510010071}}</ref> They are also associated with formation of major mineral provinces including [[Ore#Nickel-cobalt-platinum deposits|Platinum-Group Element (PGE) Deposits]], and in the Silicic LIPs, silver and gold deposits.<ref name=Bryan/> Titanium and vanadium deposits are also found in association with LIPs.<ref>M.-F. Zhou et al.; Two magma series and associated ore deposit types in the Permian Emeishan large igneous province, SW China; Lithos; Vol. 103 (2008) pp.352–368; {{doi|10.1016/j.lithos.2007.10.006}}</ref> *LIPs in the geological record have marked major changes in the hydrosphere and atmosphere, leading to major climate shifts and maybe mass extinctions of species.<ref name=Bryan/> Some of these changes were related to rapid release of greenhouse gases from the crust to the atmosphere. Thus the LIP-triggered changes may be used as cases to understand current and future environmental changes. *Plate tectonic theory explains topography using interactions between the tectonic plates, as influenced by viscous stresses created by flow within the underlying mantle. Since the mantle is extremely viscous, the mantle flow rate varies in pulses which are reflected in the lithosphere by small amplitude, long wavelength undulations. Understanding how the interaction between mantle flow and lithosphere elevation influences formation of LIPs is important to gaining insights into past mantle dynamics.<ref name=Braun>Braun, J; The many surface expressions of mantle dynamics; Nature Geosciences; VOL 3; DECEMBER 2010; {{doi|10.1038/ngeo1020}}</ref> * LIPs have played a major role in continental breakup, continental formation, new crustal additions from the upper mantle, and supercontinent cycles.<ref name=Braun/>
==Large igneous province formation== [[File:3-Devils-grade-Moses-Coulee-Cattle-Feed-Lot-PB110016.JPG|thumb|right|280px|Three Devil's grade in [[Moses Coulee]], Washington is part of the [[Columbia River Basalt Group]] LIP.]] Earth has an outer shell made of a number of discrete, moving tectonic plates floating on a solid convective mantle above a liquid core. The mantle's flow is driven by the descent of cold tectonic plates during subduction and the complementary ascent of plumes of hot material from lower levels. The surface of the Earth reflects stretching, thickening and bending of the tectonic plates as they interact.<ref name=allen>{{cite journal | last1 = Allen | first1 = Philip A | year = 2011 | title = Geodynamics: Surface impact of mantle processes | url = | journal = Nature Geoscience | volume = 4 | issue = | pages = 498–499 | doi = 10.1038/ngeo1216 | bibcode = 2011NatGe...4..498A }}</ref>
Ocean-plate creation at upwellings, spreading and subduction are well accepted fundamentals of plate tectonics, with the upwelling of hot mantle materials and the sinking of the cooler ocean plates driving the mantle convection. In this model, tectonic plates diverge at [[mid-ocean ridge]]s, where hot mantle rock flows upward to fill the space. Plate-tectonic processes account for the vast majority of Earth's volcanism.<ref name=hump>{{cite journal | last1 = Humphreys | first1 = Eugene | last2 = Schmandt | first2 = Brandon | year = 2011 | title = Looking for mantle plumes | url = | journal = Physics Today | volume = 64 | issue = 8| page = 34 | doi = 10.1063/PT.3.1217 | bibcode = 2011PhT....64h..34H }}</ref>
Beyond the effects of convectively driven motion, deep processes have other influences on the surface topography. The convective circulation drives up-wellings and down-wellings in Earth's mantle that are reflected in local surface levels. Hot mantle materials rising up in a plume can spread out radially beneath the tectonic plate causing regions of uplift.<ref name=allen/> These ascending plumes play an important role in LIP formation.
===Formation characteristics=== When created, LIPs often have an areal extent of a few million km² and volumes on the order of 1 million km³. In most cases, the majority of a basaltic LIP's volume is emplaced in less than 1 million years. One of the conundra of such LIPs' origins is to understand how enormous volumes of basaltic magma are formed and erupted over such short time scales, with effusion rates up to an order of magnitude greater than mid-ocean ridge basalts.
===Formation theories=== The source of many or all LIPs are variously attributed to mantle plumes, to processes associated with plate tectonics or to meteorite impacts.
====Plume formation of LIPs==== Although most of volcanic activity on Earth is associated with subduction zones or mid-oceanic ridges, there are significant regions of long-lived, extensive volcanism, known as [[hotspot (geology)|hotspots]], which are only indirectly related to plate tectonics. The [[Hawaiian–Emperor seamount chain]], located on the [[Pacific Plate]], is one example, tracing millions of years of relative motion as the plate moves over the [[Hawaii hotspot]]. Numerous hotspots of varying size and age have been identified across the world. These hotspots move slowly with respect to one another, but move an order of magnitude more quickly with respect to tectonic plates, providing evidence that they are not directly linked to tectonic plates.<ref name=hump/>
The origin of hotspots remains controversial. Hotspots that reach the Earth’s surface may have three distinct origins. The deepest probably originate from the boundary between the lower mantle and the core; roughly 15–20% have characteristics such as presence of a linear chain of sea mounts with increasing ages, LIPs at the point of origin of the track, low shear wave velocity indicating high temperatures below the current location of the track, and ratios of He<sup>3</sup> to He<sup>4</sup> which are judged consistent with a deep origin. Others such as the [[Pitcairn hotspot|Pitcairn]], Samoan and Tahitian hotspots appear to originate at the top of large, transient, hot lava domes (termed superswells) in the mantle. The remainder appear to originate in the upper mantle and have been suggested to result from the breakup of subducting lithosphere.<ref name=cour>Vincent Courtillot, Anne Davaille, Jean Besse, & Joann Stock ;Three distinct types of hotspots in the Earth’s mantle; Earth and Planetary Science Letters; V. 205; 2003; pp.295–308</ref>
Recent imaging of the region below known hotspots (e.g., [[Yellowstone hotspot|Yellowstone]] and Hawaii) using seismic-wave [[tomography]] has produced mounting evidence that supports relatively narrow, deep-origin, convective plumes that are limited in region compared to the large-scale plate tectonic circulation in which they are imbedded. Images reveal continuous but torturous vertical paths with varying quantities of hotter material, even at depths where crystallographic transformations are predicted to occur.<ref>E. Humphreys and B. Schmandt; Looking for Mantle Plumes; Physics Today; August 2011; pp. 34- 39</ref>{{Clarification needed|date=June 2018}}
====Plate-related stress formation of LIPs==== A major alternative to the plume model is a model in which ruptures are caused by plate-related stresses that fractured the lithosphere, allowing melt to reach the surface from shallow heterogeneous sources. The high volumes of molten material that form the LIPs is postulated to be caused by convection in the upper mantle, which is secondary to the convection driving tectonic plate motion.<ref name= Hagstrum >J.T. Hagstrum; Antipodal hotspots and bipolar catastrophes: Were oceanic large-body impacts the cause?; Earth and Planetary Science Letters; Vol 236; (2005) pp. 13–27; {{doi|10.1016/j.epsl.2005.02.020}}</ref>
====Early formed reservoir outpourings==== It has been proposed that geochemical evidence supports an early-formed reservoir that survived in the Earth's mantle for about 4.5 billion years. Molten material is postulated to have originated from this reservoir, contributing the Baffin Island flood basalt ~60 million years ago. Basalts from the Ontong Java plateau show similar isotopic and trace element signatures proposed for the early-Earth reservoir.<ref>Matthew G. Jackson & Richard W. Carlson; An ancient recipe for flood-basalt genesis; Nature (2011) {{doi|10.1038/nature10326}}</ref>
====Meteorite-induced formation==== Seven pairs of hotspots and LIPs located on opposite sides of the earth have been noted; analyses indicate this coincident antipodal location is highly unlikely to be random. The hotspot pairs include a large igneous province with continental volcanism opposite an oceanic hotspot. Oceanic impacts of large meteorites are expected to have high efficiency in converting energy into seismic waves. These waves would propagate around the world and reconverge close to the antipodal position; small variations are expected as the seismic velocity varies depending upon the route characteristics along which the waves propagate. As the waves focus on the antipodal position, they put the crust at the focal point under significant stress and are proposed to rupture it, creating antipodal pairs. When the meteorite impacts a continent, the lower efficiency of kinetic energy conversion into seismic energy is not expected to create an antipodal hotspot.<ref name= Hagstrum/>
A second impact-related model of hotspot and LIP formation has been suggested in which minor hotspot volcanism was generated at large-body impact sites and flood basalt volcanism was triggered antipodally by focused seismic energy [13,14]. This model has been challenged because impacts are generally considered seismically too inefficient [15], and the Deccan Traps of India were not antipodal to, and began erupting several Myr before, the end-Cretaceous Chicxulub impact in Mexico. In addition, no clear example of impact-induced volcanism, unrelated to melt sheets, has been confirmed at any known terrestrial crater.<ref name= Hagstrum/>
==Classification== In 1992, Coffin and Eldholm initially defined the term "large igneous province" (LIP) as representing a variety of mafic igneous provinces with areal extent >1 x 10<sup>5</sup> km<sup>2</sup> that represented "massive crustal emplacements of predominantly mafic (Mg- and Fe-rich) extrusive and intrusive rock, and originated via processes other than 'normal' seafloor spreading."<ref>Coffin, M.F., Eldholm, O. (Eds.), 1991. Large Igneous Provinces: JOI/USSAC workshop report. The University of Texas at Austin Institute for Geophysics Technical Report, p. 114.</ref><ref>Coffin, M.F., Eldholm, O., 1992. Volcanism and continental break-up: a global compilation of large igneous provinces. In: Storey, B.C., Alabaster, T., Pankhurst, R.J. (Eds.), Magmatism and the Causes of Continental Break-up. Geological Society of London Special Publication, vol. 68, pp. 17–30.</ref><ref>Coffin, M.F., Eldholm, O., 1994. Large igneous provinces: crustal structure, dimensions, and external consequences. Reviews of Geophysics Vol. 32, pp. 1–36.</ref> That original definition included continental [[flood basalt]]s, [[oceanic plateau]]s, large [[dike swarm]]s (the eroded roots of a volcanic province), and [[passive margin|volcanic rifted margins]]. Most of these LIPs consist of basalt, but some contain large volumes of associated [[rhyolite]] (e.g. the [[Columbia River Basalt Group]] in the western United States); the rhyolite is typically very dry compared to island arc rhyolites, with much higher eruption temperatures (850 °C to 1000 °C) than normal rhyolites.
Since 1992 the definition of 'LIP' has been expanded and refined, and remains a work in progress. Some new definitions of the term 'LIP' include large granitic provinces such as those found in the Andes Mountains of South America and in western North America. Comprehensive taxonomies have been developed to focus technical discussions.
In 2008, Bryan and Ernst refined the definition to narrow it somewhat: "Large Igneous Provinces are magmatic provinces with areal extents >1 x 10<sup>5</sup> km<sup>2</sup>, igneous volumes >1 x 10<sup>5</sup> km<sup>3</sup> and maximum lifespans of ∼50 Myr that have intraplate tectonic settings or geochemical affinities, and are characterised by igneous pulse(s) of short duration (∼1–5 Myr), during which a large proportion (>75%) of the total igneous volume has been emplaced. They are dominantly mafic, but also can have significant ultramafic and silicic components, and some are dominated by silicic magmatism." This definition places emphasis on the high magma emplacement rate characteristics of the LIP event and excludes seamounts, seamount groups, submarine ridges and anomalous seafloor crust.<ref name=Bryan_2>S.E. Bryan & R.E. Ernst; Revised definition of Large Igneous Provinces (LIPs); Earth-Science Reviews Vol. 86 (2008) pp. 175–202</ref>
'LIP' is now frequently used to also describe voluminous areas of, not just mafic, but all types of igneous rocks. Sub-categorization of LIPs into Large Volcanic Provinces (LVP) and Large Plutonic Provinces (LPP), and including rocks produced by 'normal' plate tectonic processes, has been proposed. Further, the threshold to be included as a LIP has been lowered to >5x10<sup>4</sup> km<sup>2</sup>.<ref name=Sheth/> The working taxonomy, focused heavily on geochemistry, which will be used to structure examples below, is: *Large igneous provinces (LIP) **Large volcanic provinces (LVP) ***Large rhyolitic provinces (LRPs) ***Large andesitic provinces (LAPs) ***Large basaltic provinces (LBPs): oceanic, or continental flood basalts ***Large basaltic–rhyolitic provinces (LBRPs) **Large plutonic provinces (LPP) ***Large granitic provinces (LGP) ***Large mafic plutonic provinces
[[File:The difference between a sill and a dike.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Illustration showing a vertical [[Dike (geology)|dike]] and a horizontal sill.]] Aerally extensive [[dike swarm]]s, [[Sill (geology)|sill]] provinces, and large layered [[ultramafic]] intrusions are indicators of LIPs, even when other evidence is not now observable. The upper basalt layers of older LIPs may have been removed by erosion or deformed by tectonic plate collisions occurring after the layer is formed. This is especially likely for earlier periods such as the [[Paleozoic]] and [[Proterozoic]].<ref name=Bryan_2 />
Giant dyke swarms having lengths >300 km<ref name=ErnstButler97>{{Citation | last1 = Ernst | first1 = R. E. | last2 = Buchan | first2 = K. L., | contribution = Giant Radiating Dyke Swarms: Their Use in Identifying Pre-Mesozoic Large Igneous Provinces and Mantle Plumes | editor-last1 = Mahoney | editor-first1 = J. J. | editor-last2 = Coffin | editor-first2 = M. F. (editors), | title = Large Igneous Provinces: Continental, Oceanic and Flood Volcanism (Geophysical Monograph 100) | pages = 297 | publisher = American Geophysical Union | place = Washington D.C. | publication-date = 1997 | isbn = 0-87590-082-8}}</ref> are a common record of severely eroded LIPs. Both radial and linear dyke swarm configurations exist. Radial swarms with an areal extent >2000 km and linear swarms extending >1000 km are known. The linear dyke swarms often have a high proportion of dykes relative to country rocks, particularly when the width of the linear field is less than 100 km. The dykes have a typical width of 20–100 meters, although [[ultramafic]] dykes with widths greater than 1000 meters have been reported.<ref name=Bryan_2 />
Dykes are typically sub-vertical to vertical. When upward flowing (dyke-forming) magma encounters horizontal boundaries or weaknesses, such as between layers in a sedimentary deposit, the magma can flow horizontally creating a sill. Some sill provinces have areal extents >1000 km.<ref name=Bryan_2 />
==Correlations with LIP formation==
===Correlation with hot-spots=== The early volcanic activity of major [[Hotspot (geology)|hotspots]], postulated to result from deep mantle plumes, is frequently accompanied by flood basalts. These flood basalt eruptions have resulted in large accumulations of basaltic lavas emplaced at a rate greatly exceeding that seen in contemporary volcanic processes. Continental rifting commonly follows flood basalt volcanism. Flood basalt provinces may also occur as a consequence of the initial hot-spot activity in ocean basins as well as on continents. It is possible to track the hot spot back to the flood basalts of a large igneous province; the table below correlates large igneous provinces with the track of a specific hot spot.<ref name=Rich>M.A. Richards, R.A. Duncan, V.E. Courtillot; ''Flood Basalts and Hot-Spot Tracks: Plume Heads and Tails''; SCIENCE, VOL. 246 (1989) 103–108</ref><ref name="Antretter">Antretter, M.; Riisager, P.; Hall, S.; Zhao, X.; and Steinberger, B. (2004). [http://sp.lyellcollection.org/cgi/content/abstract/229/1/21 Modelled palaeolatitudes for the Louisville hot spot and the Ontong Java Plateau], in ''Origin and Evolution of the Ontong Java Plateau'' Geological Society, London, Special Publications, v. 229, p. 21-30. {{doi|10.1144/GSL.SP.2004.229.01.03}}.</ref>
{| style="border-collapse: collapse" class="wikitable sortable" !align="right"| '''Province''' !align="right"| '''Region''' !align="center"| '''Hotspot''' !align="left"|'''Reference''' |- |[[Columbia River Basalt Group|Columbia River Basalt]] |Northwestern USA |[[Yellowstone hotspot]] |<ref name=Rich/><ref name=Nash/> |- |[[Ethiopia-Yemen Continental Flood Basalts|Ethiopia-Yemen Flood Basalts]] |[[Ethiopia]], [[Yemen]] | |<ref name=Rich/> |- |[[North Atlantic Igneous Province]] |Northern Canada, [[Greenland]], the [[Faeroe Islands]], [[Norway]], Ireland and [[Scotland]] |[[Iceland hotspot]] |<ref name=Rich/> |-
|[[Deccan Traps]] |[[India]] & southern [[Pakistan]] |[[Réunion hotspot]] |<ref name=Rich/> |- |[[Rahjamal Traps]] |[[India|Eastern India]] |[[Ninety East Ridge]] |<ref name=Weis/><ref name=Verz/> |- |[[Kerguelen Plateau]] |Indian Ocean |[[Kerguelen hotspot]] |<ref name="Weis"/> |- |[[Ontong-Java Plateau]] |Pacific Ocean |[[Louisville hotspot]] |<ref name=Rich/><ref name="Antretter"/>
|- |[[Paraná and Etendeka traps]] |[[Brazil]]–[[Namibia]] |[[Tristan hotspot]] |<ref name=Rich/>
|- |[[Karoo-Ferrar|Karoo-Ferrar Province]] |South Africa, [[Antarctica]], Australia & [[New Zealand]] |[[Marion Island]] |<ref name=Rich/> |- |[[Caribbean large igneous province]] |[[Caribbean-Colombian oceanic plateau]] |[[Galápagos hotspot]] |<ref>Sur l'âge des trapps basaltiques (On the ages of flood basalt events); [[Vincent Courtillot|Vincent E. Courtillot]] & Paul R. Renne; Comptes Rendus Geoscience; Vol: 335 Issue: 1, January 2003; pp: 113–140</ref><ref>Kaj Hoernle, Folkmar Hauff and Paul van den Bogaard, ''70 m.y. history (139–69 Ma) for the Caribbean large igneous province'', Geology; August 2004; v. 32; no. 8; p. 697-700 [http://geology.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/32/8/697 Abstract]</ref> |- |[[Mackenzie Large Igneous Province]] |[[Canadian Shield]] |[[Mackenzie hotspot]] |<ref>{{cite book|last=Ernst|first=Richard E.|author2=Buchan, Kenneth L.|title=Mantle plumes: their identification through time|publisher=[[Geological Society of America]]|year=2001|pages=143, 145, 146, 147, 148, 259|isbn=0-8137-2352-3}}</ref> |}
===Relationship to extinction events=== Eruptions or emplacements of LIPs appear to have, in some cases, occurred simultaneously with [[oceanic anoxic event]]s and [[extinction event]]s. The most important examples are the [[Deccan Traps]] ([[Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event]]), the [[Karoo-Ferrar]] ([[Pliensbachian-Toarcian extinction]]), the [[Central Atlantic Magmatic Province]] ([[Triassic-Jurassic extinction event]]), and the [[Siberian traps]] ([[Permian-Triassic extinction event]]).
Several mechanisms are proposed to explain the association of LIPs with extinction events. The eruption of basaltic LIPs onto the earth's surface releases large volumes of sulfate gas, which forms sulfuric acid in the atmosphere; this absorbs heat and causes substantial cooling (e.g., the [[Laki (volcano)|Laki]] eruption in Iceland, 1783). Oceanic LIPs can reduce oxygen in seawater by either direct oxidation reactions with metals in hydrothermal fluids or by causing algal blooms that consume large amounts of oxygen.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.2113/gselements.1.5.289 |last=Kerr |first=AC |ref=CITEREFKerr2005 |date=December 2005 |title=Oceanic LIPS: Kiss of death |journal=Elements |volume=1 |pages=289–292 |issue=5 }}</ref>
===Ore deposits=== Large igneous provinces are associated with a handful of ore deposit types including: * [[Nickel|Ni]]–[[Copper|Cu]] [[Platinum group|PGE]]s * [[Porphyry (geology)|Porphyries]] * [[Iron oxide copper gold ore deposits|Iron oxide copper gold (IOCG)]] * [[Kimberlite]]s
==Examples== {{see also|World's largest eruptions}} There are a number of well documented examples of large igneous provinces identified by geological research.

''Journal of Geodynamics'', Volume 35, Issue 3, April 2003, Pages 289–302</ref> |- |[[Ontong-Java Plateau]] |Pacific Ocean |~122 |1.86 |8.4 |[[Manihiki Plateau]] and [[Hikurangi Plateau]] |<ref name=Ross/>
|- |[[High Arctic Large Igneous Province]] |[[Svalbard]], [[Franz Josef Land]], [[Sverdrup Basin Magmatic Province|Sverdrup Basin]], [[Amerasian Basin]], and northern [[Greenland]] |130-60 |>1.0 | | |<ref name="Tegner_etal_2011">{{Cite journal |last=Tegner C. |last2=Storey M. |last3=Holm P.M. |last4=Thorarinsson S.B. |last5=Zhao X. |last6=Lo C.-H. |last7=Knudsen M.F. |title=Magmatism and Eurekan deformation in the High Arctic Large Igneous Province: 40Ar–39Ar age of Kap Washington Group volcanics, North Greenland |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012821X10008204 |journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters |volume=303 |issue=3–4 |pages=203–214 |doi=10.1016/j.epsl.2010.12.047|bibcode=2011E&PSL.303..203T }}</ref>

"Warakurna large igneous province: A new Mesoproterozoic large igneous province in west-central Australia." ''Geology'' (2004) Volume 32; pp.105–108 {{doi|10.1130/G20171.1}}</ref> |}
=== Large rhyolitic provinces (LRPs) === These LIPs are composed dominantly of [[felsic]] materials. Examples include: *Whitsunday * Sierra Madre Occidental (Mexico) * Malani * Chon Aike (Argentina) * Gawler (Australia)
===Large andesitic provinces (LAPs)=== These LIPs are comprised dominantly of [[andesitic]] materials. Examples include: * Island arcs such as Indonesia and Japan * Active continental margins such as the Andes and the Cascades * Continental collision zones such as the Anatolia-Iran zone
===Large basaltic provinces (LBPs)=== This subcategory includes most of the provinces included in the original LIP classifications. It is composed of continental flood basalts, oceanic flood basalts, and diffuse provinces.
====Continental flood basalts==== * [[Ethiopia-Yemen Continental Flood Basalts]] * [[Columbia River Basalt Group]] * [[Deccan Traps]] (India) * [[Coppermine River Group]] (Canadian Shield) * [[Equatorial Atlantic Magmatic Province]] ([[Maranhão]], Brazil-Ghana) * [[Midcontinent Rift System]], Great Lakes Region, North America * [[Paraná and Etendeka traps]] ([[Paraná (state)|Paraná]], Brazil–NE Namibia) * [[Brazilian Highlands]] * [[Río de la Plata Craton]] (Uruguay) * [[Karoo-Ferrar]] (South Africa–Antarctica) * [[Siberian Traps]] (Russia) * [[Emeishan Traps]] (western China) * [[Central Atlantic Magmatic Province]] (eastern United States and Canada, northern South America, northwest Africa) * [[North Atlantic Igneous Province]] (includes basalts in Greenland, Iceland, Ireland, Scotland, and Faroes) * [[High Arctic Large Igneous Province]] (includes the [[Ellesmere Island Volcanics]], [[Strand Fiord Formation]], [[Alpha Ridge]], [[Franz Josef Land]], and [[Svalbard]])
====Oceanic flood basalts/ oceanic plateaus==== * [[Azores Plateau]] (Atlantic Ocean) * [[Wrangellia Terrane]] (Alaska and Canada) * [[Caribbean large igneous province]] (Caribbean Sea) * [[Kerguelen Plateau]] (Indian Ocean) * [[Ontong Java Plateau]], [[Manihiki Plateau]] and [[Hikurangi Plateau]] (southwest Pacific Ocean) * [[Jameson Land]]
===Large basaltic–rhyolitic provinces (LBRPs)=== * Snake River Plain – Oregon High Lava Plains * Dongargarh (Ethiopia)
===Large plutonic provinces (LPP)===
====Large granitic provinces (LGP)==== * Patagonia * Peru–Chile Batholith * Coast Range Batholith (NW US)
====Other large plutonic provinces==== *Parts of [[Central Atlantic Magmatic Province]] (eastern United States and Canada, northern South America, northwest Africa)
===Related structures===
====Volcanic rifted margins==== [[File:mantleplume.png|right|240px|thumb|Extension thins the crust. Magma reaches the surface through radiating sills and dikes, forming basalt flows, as well as deep and shallow magma chambers below the surface. The crust gradually thins due to thermal subsidence, and originally horizontal basalt flows are rotated to become seaward dipping reflectors.]]
[[Volcanic passive margin|Volcanic rifted margins]] are found on the boundary of large igneous provinces. Volcanic margins form when rifting is accompanied by significant mantle melting, with volcanism occurring before and/or during continental breakup. Volcanic rifted margins are characterized by: a transitional crust composed of [[basalt]]ic [[igneous rock]]s, including [[lava]] flows, [[sill (geology)|sills]], [[Dike (geology)|dikes]], and [[gabbro]]s, high volume basalt flows, seaward-dipping reflector sequences (SDRS) of basalt flows that were rotated during the early stages of breakup, limited passive-margin subsidence during and after breakup, and the presence of a lower crust with anomalously high seismic P-wave velocities in lower crustal bodies (LCBs), indicative of lower temperature, dense media.
Example of volcanic margins include: * The Yemen margin * The East Australian margin * The West Indian margin * The Hatton–Rockal margin * The US East Coast * The mid-Norwegian margin * The Brazilian margins * The Namibian margin
====Dike swarms==== [[File:Mackenzie dike swarm.png|thumb|right|Map of the Mackenzie dike swarm in Canada]]
A dike swarm is a large geological structure consisting of a major group of parallel, linear, or radially oriented dikes intruded within continental crust. They consist of several to hundreds of dikes emplaced more or less contemporaneously during a single intrusive event, and are magmatic and stratigraphic. Such dike swarms are the roots of a volcanic province. Examples include: * [[Mackenzie dike swarm]] (Canadian Shield) * [[Long Range dikes]] (Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada) * [[Mistassini dike swarm]] (western Quebec, Canada) * [[Matachewan dike swarm]] (northern Ontario, Canada) * Sorachi Plateau and Belt (Hokkaido, Japan) * Uralian dike swarm (Russia)<ref name="Puchkov2016">{{cite journal | url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/11035897.2015.1118406 | title=A Devonian >2000-km-long dolerite dyke swarm-belt and associated basalts along the Urals-Novozemelian fold-belt: part of an East-European (Baltica) LIP tracing the Tuzo Superswell | first=Victor | last=Puchkov | first2=Richard E. | last2=Ernst | first3=Michael A. | last3=Hamilton | first4=Ulf | last4=Söderlund | first5=Nina | last5=Sergeeva | journal=GFF | year=2016 | volume=138 | pages=6–16 | doi=10.1080/11035897.2015.1118406}}</ref>
====Sills==== A series of related sills that were formed essentially contemporaneously (within several million years) from related dikes comprise a LIP if their area is sufficiently large. Examples include: * [[Winagami sill complex]] (northwestern Alberta, Canada) * [[Bushveld Igneous Complex]] (South Africa) with an area of over 66,000 km<sup>2</sup> (25,000 sq mi), and a thickness reaching 9 kilometres (5.6 mi) thick.
==See also== *[[Igneous rock]] *[[Geologic province]] *[[Hotspot (geology)|Hotspots]] *[[List of flood basalt provinces]] *[[Lithosphere]] *[[Oceanic plateau]] *[[Orogeny]] *[[Peridotite]] *[[Pluton]] *[[Subduction zone]] *[[Supervolcano]] *[[Volcanic passive margin]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}} [[File:Small Khitan Inscription.jpg|thumb|Detail of Khitan small script on the epitaph of Yelü Dilie (1026-1092)]] The '''list of Khitan inscriptions''' comprises a list of the corpus of known inscriptions written in the [[Khitan large script]] and the [[Khitan small script]]. These two [[Writing system|scripts]] were used by the [[Khitan people]] in northern [[China]] during the 10th through 12th centuries for writing the extinct [[Khitan language]]. The Khitan language was in use during the [[Liao Dynasty]] (907–1125), the [[Kara-Khitan Khanate]] (1124–1218) and the [[Jin dynasty (1115–1234)]], but the last recorded Khitan speaker, [[Yelü Chucai]], died in 1243, and the language probably became extinct soon afterwards.{{harvnb|Kane|2009|p=4}} There are no surviving examples of printed texts in the Khitan language, and aside from five example Khitan large characters with Chinese glosses in a book on calligraphy, ''Shūshǐ huìyào'' (書史會要), written by Tao Zongyi (陶宗儀) in the mid 14th century, there are no Chinese glossaries or dictionaries of Khitan.{{harvnb|Kane|2009|pp=169–170}} The Khitan language is therefore little understood, and the two Khitan writing systems are only partially deciphered.{{harvnb|Kane|2009|p=ix}} The main source of Khitan texts are monumental inscriptions, mostly comprising memorial tablets buried in the tombs of Khitan nobility.{{harvnb|Kane|2009|p=4}} Only one monument in a Khitan script was known before the 20th century, the ''Record of the Younger Brother of the Emperor of the Great Jin Dynasty'' (''Langjun xingji'' 郎君行記), which has stood in front of the tomb of [[Wu Zetian|Empress Wu of Tang]] since at least 1618. Until the 1920s it was believed to be written in the [[Jurchen script]]. Only after the discovery of the memorial tablets of [[Emperor Xingzong of Liao]] and his consort was it realized that the ''Record of the Younger Brother of the Emperor'' and the Liao-dynasty memorial tablets were both written in a Khitan script.{{harvnb|Kane|2009|p=1}} Several more memorial tablets in the same script were discovered during the 1930s, including memorials for [[Emperor Daozong of Liao]] and his consort. Initially it was not clear whether the script inscribed on these memorial tablets was the Khitan large script, recorded to have been devised in 920, or the Khitan small script, recorded to have been devised about 925. A different, unknown script, which appeared more similar to Chinese (incorporating many [[Chinese character|characters]] borrowed directly from Chinese), had been discovered on a temple monument in 1935, as well as on a memorial to Xiao Xiaozhong in 1951; and in 1962 [[Jin Guangping]] suggested that these two monuments were written using the Khitan large script, and that the ''Record of the Younger Brother of the Emperor'' and the imperial memorial tablets were written using the Khitan small script.{{harvnb|Kane|2009|p=2}} This identification of the two Khitan scripts is now widely accepted. There are about 15 known monuments with inscriptions in the Khitan large script, ranging in date from 986 to 1176, and about 40 known monuments with inscriptions in the Khitan small script, ranging in date from 1053 to 1171.{{harvnb|Wu Yingzhe|2012}} The two scripts are mutually exclusive (never occurring together on the same monument), but it is not known why the Khitan people used two different scripts, or what determined the choice of which script to use. In addition to monumental inscriptions, short inscriptions in both Khitan scripts have also been found on tomb murals and rock paintings, and on various portable artefacts such as mirrors, amulets, [[paiza]] (tablets of authority given to officials and envoys), and special non-circulation coins. A number of bronze official [[Seal (emblem)|seals]] with the seal face inscribed in the Khitan large script are also known. The Khitan characters on these seals are engraved in a convoluted calligraphic style that imitates the Chinese "nine-fold" [[seal script]] style of calligraphy. {{GeoGroupTemplate}} ==Monumental inscriptions in the Khitan large script== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" |- ! width="20%" | Monument !! width="10%" | Image !! width="5%" | Date !! width="20%" | Place of discovery !! width="10%" | Year of discovery !! width="15%" | Current Location !! class="unsortable" width="20%" | Description |- | Commemoration of a battle victory by Hutenu (Yelü Zhaosan 耶律趙三) || || 1084 || Salbar Mountains, [[Mörön, Khentii|Mörön]], [[Khentii Province]]
[[Mongolia]]
{{coord|47.40|110.30|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Commemoration of a battle victory by Hutenu}} || {{sort|1950|1950s}} || In situ || 4 lines, 25 characters.{{Cite journal | author=Sun Bojun 孫伯君 | script-title=zh:蒙古國肯特省契丹大字刻石考釋 | journal=Shije Minzu 世界民族 | year=2006 | issue=4 | pages=44–52 | url=http://www.docin.com/p-63761660.html | issn=1006-8287 | language=Chinese }} |- | Inscribed sarcophagous || || || Gengzhangzi Village, [[Jianchang County]]
Liaoning
{{coord|40.76|119.82|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Inscribed sarcophagous}} || 1977 || Jianchang County Museum || 8 lines, 19 characters (badly damaged as the sarcophagous was cut into three pieces).{{harvnb|Liu Fengzhu|Yu Baolin|1990|p=392}} |- | Memorial at Jing'an Temple (靜安寺) erected by the Lady of Lanling Commandery (蘭陵郡夫人), the wife of Yelü Changyun || || 1072 || Ruins of Jing'an Temple, [[Ningcheng County]]
[[Inner Mongolia]]

illegible).{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|p=200}} |- | Epitaph for an unknown person || || 1056 || Unknown (only known from a photograph of a rubbing shown to Liu Fengzhu) || {{sort|1997|before 1997}} || Unknown || 27 lines.{{harvnb|Liu Pujiang|2003}} |- | Epitaph for Court Attendant Dorlipun 多羅里本郎君 (1037–1080) || || 1081 || Unknown || 1999 || Ar Horqin Banner Museum || 21 lines, 800 characters.{{Cite pages=50–55 | language=Chinese }} |- | Epitaph for Court Attendant Li Ai 李爱郎君{{#tag:ref|This monument was previously known as the Yingli period monument (''Yingli bei'' 應歷碑), but the characters that were originally interpreted as meaning the Yingli 應歷 period (951–969) are now interpreted as meaning the Dading 大定 period (1161–1189), so what was once thought to be the earliest Khitan memorial in now thought to be the latest in date.{{Cite web | author=Li Junyi 李俊義 | script-title=zh:薪傳火繼，拯救絕學——契丹文字專家劉鳳翥先生來赤峰學院講學紀要 | date=2009-09-26 | url=http://hi.baidu.com/%BE%B2%D0%E9%C9%BD%B7%BF%D6%F7%C8%CB/blog/item/0b110e00e43bde09728da52f.html | accessdate=2010-12-22 | language=Chinese }}|group=note}} || || 1176 || Unknown (only known from a rubbing) || {{sort|1985|before 1985}} || Unknown || 16 lines, 470 characters.{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|p=202}} |- | Epitaph for the Grand Preceptor (太師) || || 1056 || Unknown (only known from a rubbing) || {{sort|1939|before 1939}} || Unknown || 40 lines, 1,800 characters.{{harvnb|Liu Fengzhu|Yu Baolin|1990|p=391}}{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|pp=200–201}} |- | Epitaph for the Grand Prince of the North 北大王 {{coord|40.40|117.50|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Xiao Zhonggong}} || 1942 || Hebei Province Office of Cultural Relics || 50 lines, 2,442 characters; 3 lines, 9 characters on the lid.{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|pp=208–209}}{{harvnb|Kane|2009|p=12}} |- | Epitaph for Yelü Jiuli 耶律糺里 or Yelü Gui 耶律貴 (1061–1102){{#tag:ref|The name of the official commemorated by this inscriptions has been variously given as Yelü Guiyexi 耶律貴也稀, Yelü Gui 耶律貴, Yelü Diligu 耶律迪里姑, Yelü Gui-Diligu 耶律貴·迪里姑 and Yelü Yiliyan 耶律夷里衍.|group=note}} || || 1102 || Unknown || 2002 (probably robbed from a tomb in the 1990s) || || 31 lines, 1,020 characters.{{Cite journal | author=Liu Pujiang 劉浦江 | script-title=zh:關於契丹小字《耶律糺裏墓誌銘》的若乾問題 | journal=Beida Shixue 北大史學 | year=2009 | issue=14 | url=http://www.zggds.pku.edu.cn/004/001/175.pdf | language=Chinese | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707025108/http://www.zggds.pku.edu.cn/004/001/175.pdf | archivedate=7 July 2011 | df=dmy-all }} |- | Epitaph for Yelü Cite 耶律慈特 (1043–1081) || || 1082 || Baiyinwendu, [[Ar Horqin Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|43.60|120.40|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Yelü Cite}} || 1997 || Ar Horqin Banner Museum || 30 lines, 930 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Dilie 耶律迪烈 (1026–1092) || [[File:Memorial tablet of Yelu Dilie.jpg|100px|Memorial tablet for Yelü Dilie]] || 1092 || Gahaitu Township, [[Jarud Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|44.92|121.06|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Yelü Dilie}} || 1995 || Liao and Jin City Wall Museum, Beijing || 32 lines, 1,740 characters; 9 lines on the lid. |- | Epitaph for Yelü (Han) Dilie 耶律(韓)迪烈 (1034–1100) || || 1101 || Baiyinhan Mountain, Baiyinwula, [[Bairin Left Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|44.37|118.89|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Han Dilie}} || 1996 || Liao Shangjing Museum || 34 lines, 1,350 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Gaoshi 耶律高十 or Han Gaoshi 韓高十 (1015–?) || || {{sort|1076|c.1076}} || Baiyinhan Mountain, Baiyinwula, [[Bairin Left Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|44.35|118.87|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Han Gaoshi}} || 1995 || Liao Shangjing Museum || 26 lines, 750 characters. Lower half of inscription is missing. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Hongben 耶律弘本 (1041–1110), the Imperial Grand Uncle 皇太叔祖 (1041–1110), the son of Emperor Xingzong and Empress Renyi || || 1110 || Mausoleum of Emperor Xingzong, [[Bairin Right Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|44.36|118.52|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Yelü Hongben}} || 1997 || Bairin Right Banner Museum || 25 lines, 807 characters; 3 lines, 15 characters in seal script on the lid. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Hongbian 耶律弘辨 or Yelü Hongyong 耶律弘用 (1054–1086), the brother-in-law of the Imperial Consort of Song and Wei || || 1100 || Orgon Tal, [[Jarud Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|44.778|120.727|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Yelü Hongbian}} || 1996 || Jarud Banner Cultural Relics Office || 32 lines, 900 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Jue 耶律玦 (1014–1070) || || 1072 || || || Private museum at Xinhui, Aohan Banner || 46 lines, 2,000 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Nu 耶律奴 (1041–1098) || || 1099 || Yaoyamen Village, [[Fuxin Mongol Autonomous County|Fuxin]]
Liaoning
{{coord|41.975|121.900|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Yelü Nu}} || 1999 || Fuxin Museum || 48 lines, 1,274 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Renxian 耶律仁先 || || 1072 || Lianhuashan Village, [[Beipiao]]
Liaoning
{{coord|41.873|121.248|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Yelü Renxian}} || 1983 || Liaoning Cultural Relics and Archeology Research Institute || 70 lines, 4,500 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Taishi 耶律太師 (1038–1101), the son of Yelü Xiangwen || || {{sort|1101|c.1101}} || || 2009 || Ethnic Museum of Inner Mongolia University || 26 lines, 1,000 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Xiangwen 耶律詳穩 (1010–1091), the father of Yelü Taishi || || 1091 || || 2007 || Ethnic Museum of Inner Mongolia University || 48 lines, 1,600 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Zhixian 耶律智先 || || 1094 || Lianhuashan Village, [[Beipiao]]
Liaoning
{{coord|41.873|121.250|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Yelü Zhixian}} || 1998 || Beipiao Museum || 21 lines, 1,000 characters. |- | Epitaph for Yelü Zongjiao 耶律宗教 (992–1053) || || 1053 || Gaoqi Village, [[Beizhen]]
Liaoning
{{coord|41.53|121.68|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Epitaph for Yelü Zongjiao}} || 1991 || [[Beizhen]] Cultural Relics Office || 36 lines, 1,000 characters |- | Jade tablets from the supposed mausoleum of [[Emperor Jingzong of Liao]] || || || Xinli Tomb M2, at [[Yiwulü Mountain]] near Futun village, [[Beizhen]]
[[Liaoning]]{{coord|41.652|121.762|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Supposed mausoleum of Emperor Jingzong of Liao}} || 2015–2018 || || Unknown.{{Cite web | title=Significant achievements of Mausoleum archaeology from Liao Dynasty in Yiwulu Mountain | url=http://kaogu.cssn.cn/ywb/news/new_discoveries_1/201810/t20181031_4767419.shtml | date=31 October 2018 | accessdate=23 November 2011 }} |- | Record of the Younger Brother of the Emperor of the Great Jin Dynasty (''Da Jin huangdi dutong jinglüe Langjun xingji'' 大金皇弟都統經略郎君行記) || [[File:Da Jin huang di dutong jinglüe langjun xingji 大金皇弟都統經略郎君行記.jpg|100px|Rubbing of the Record of the Younger Brother of the Emperor of the Great Jin Dynasty]] || 1134 || [[Qianling Mausoleum]], [[Qian County]]
[[Shaanxi]]
{{coord|34.575|108.220|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Record of the Younger Brother of the Emperor of the Great Jin Dynasty}} || {{sort|1618|first recorded in 1618}} || In front of the tomb of Empress Wu of the Tang at Qianling Mausoleum || 5 lines, 97 characters on one side, with corresponding Chinese text on the other side (the only known bilingual Chinese-Khitan text).{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|pp=208}} |- | Record of the Younger Brother of the Emperor of the Great Jin Dynasty (incomplete copy) || || 1134 || [[Qianling Mausoleum]], [[Qian County]]
[[Shaanxi]]
{{coord|34.575|108.220|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Record of the Younger Brother of the Emperor of the Great Jin Dynasty}} || 1982 || Qianling Mausoleum Museum || A copy of the text of the memorial in front of the tomb of Empress Wu, recovered from the ruins of a sacrificial hall at the Qianling Mausoleum, but only one quarter of text remaining. |- |} ==Other inscriptions in the Khitan small script== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" |- ! width="20%" | Object !! width="10%" | Image !! width="5%" | Date !! width="20%" | Place of discovery !! width="10%" | Year of discovery !! width="15%" | Current Location !! class="unsortable" width="20%" | Description |- | Bronze octagonal mirror owned by Wanyan Tong 完顏通 || || 1140–1189 || [[Da'an, Jilin|Da'an]]
Jilin
{{coord|45.50|124.30|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Bronze octagonal mirror owned by Wanyan Tong}} || 1971 || Jilin Provincial Museum || 5 lines, 16 characters.{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|pp=209–210}} |- | Bronze octagonal mirror || [[File:Khitan Small Script Bronze Mirror.JPG|100px|Bronze octagonal mirror from Inner Mongolia with a Khitan small script inscription comprising 4 characters]] || || || || Inner Mongolia Museum || 4 Khitan characters on the reverse, and three Chinese characters (寶坻) along the edge.{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|pp=210}} |- | Bronze mirror || [[File:Khitan mirror from Korea.jpg|100px|Bronze mirror from Korea with a Khitan small script inscription comprising 28 characters]] || || [[Kaesong|Kaesŏng]]
[[North Korea]]
{{coord|37.96|126.55|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Bronze mirror}} || {{sort|1912|pre-1912}} || [[National Museum of Korea]], Seoul || Khitan poem comprising 7 lines, 28 characters.{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|pp=209}} |- | "Shouchang" non-circulation lucky coin || || || || || || 4 characters on the reverse, interpreted as meaning 壽昌. |- | Fish-shaped bronze tally || [[File:Small Khitan Fish Tally.jpg|100px|Woodcut facsimile of a bronze fish tally with Small Khitan script inscription in the collection of Stephen Wootton Bushell (1844-1908)]] || || || || Originally in the collection of [[Stephen Wootton Bushell]] (1844-1908); current whereabouts unknown. || Chinese character ''tóng'' 同, with one line of Khitan small characters. |- | Fish-shaped bronze tally || || || || || || Chinese character ''tóng'' 同, with two lines of Khitan small characters. |- | Jade cup || || || || || || 2 lines, 11 Khitan small characters on bottom of the cup.{{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|pp=210–211}} |- | Yellow-glazed ceramic brush washer || || || || || || |- | Inscriptions on a pagoda || || || White Pagoda, [[Hohhot]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|40.84|111.90|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Inscriptions on a pagoda}} || || || {{harvnb|Yu Baolin|1985|pp=211}} |- | Inscriptions on the walls of a cave || || || Balahada Cave (巴拉哈達洞), [[Horqin Right Middle Banner]]
Inner Mongolia || || || {{harvnb|Chinggeltei|1985|p=625}} |- | Inscriptions on a Liao dynasty tomb mural || || || Bao Mountain, [[Ar Horqin Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|44.073|119.666|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Inscriptions on a Liao dynasty tomb mural}} || 1996 || || Short inscription on a mural. |- | Inscriptions on a painted wooden coffin || || || [[Ongniud Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|42.93|119.03|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Inscriptions on a painted wooden coffin}} || || Juu Uda League Cultural Relics Station || 22 characters on the colour painting of a wooden coffin. |- | Inscriptions at the Liao imperial mausoleum || || || [[Bairin Right Banner]]
Inner Mongolia
{{coord|44.36|118.50|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Inscriptions at the Liao imperial mausoleum}} || || || About 50 Khitan small character captions on murals at the east tomb. |- |} ==Khitan small script seals== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%" |- ! width="20%" | Object !! width="10%" | Date !! width="20%" | Place of discovery !! width="10%" | Year of discovery !! width="20%" | Current Location !! class="unsortable" width="20%" | Description |- | Bronze seal || || [[Gaizhou]]
Liaoning
{{coord|40.40|122.36|type:landmark_region:CN_source:Wikimapia_scale:2000|name=Bronze seal}} || 1972 || [[Liaoning Province Museum]] || Seal script form Khitan small characters. |- |} ==See also== revision.comment: Removed [[WP:NFCC]] violation(s). No valid [[WP:NFUR]] for this page. See [[WP:NFC#Implementation]]. Questions? [[WP:MCQ|Ask here]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox official post |post = Prime Minister |body = the
Republic of Benin |insignia = Flag of Benin.svg |insigniasize = 125px |insigniacaption = [[Flag of Benin]] |image = |imagesize = 120px |style = |residence = |appointer = [[List of Presidents of Benin|President of Benin]] |appointer_qualified = |precursor = |formation = 1 August 1960 |first = [[Hubert Maga]] |last = [[Lionel Zinsou]] |abolished = 6 April 2016 |succession = |salary = }} {{Politics of Benin}} This is a '''list of [[Prime Minister]]s of [[Benin]] (formerly [[Republic of Dahomey|Dahomey]])''' since the formation of the post of Prime Minister in 1960, to its abolition in 2016. A total of seven people have served as Prime Minister (not counting one Acting Prime Minister). ==Key== ;''Political parties'' *{{legend|Orange|[[Dahomeyan Democratic Rally]] (RDD)|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|Gold|[[Dahomeyan Democratic Party]] (PDD)|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|#156CC4|[[Democratic Renewal Party (Benin)|Democratic Renewal Party]] (PRD)|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|{{Cowry Forces for an Emerging Benin/meta/color}}|[[Cowry Forces for an Emerging Benin]] (FCBE)|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ;''Other factions'' *{{legend|{{Military Rule/meta/color}}|[[Benin Armed Forces|Military]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|{{Independent (politician)/meta/color}}|[[Independent politician|Independent]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ;''Status'' *{{legend|#E6E6AA|Denotes Acting Prime Minister}} ==Prime Ministers of Benin== (Dates in italics indicate ''de facto'' continuation of office) ===[[Republic of Dahomey]]=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; border:1px #aaf solid; width:90%;" |- !rowspan="2" colspan="2" | {{Abbr|No.|Number}} !rowspan="2" style="width:70px;" | Portrait !rowspan="2" | Name
{{small|(Birth–Death)}} !colspan="3" | Term of Office !rowspan="2" | Political Party |- !{{small|Took Office}} !{{small|Left Office}} !{{small|Time in Office}} |- ! style="background:Orange" | ! 1 | [[File:Hubert Maga 1961.png|70px]] | '''[[Hubert Maga]]'''
{{small|(1916–2000)}} | 1 August 1960 | 31 December 1960 | {{age in years and days|1960|8|1|1960|12|31}} | [[Dahomeyan Democratic Rally|RDD]] |- | colspan=8 align=center|''Post Abolished (31 December 1960–25 January 1964)'' |- ! style="background:Gold" | ! 2 | | '''[[Justin Ahomadégbé-Tomêtin]]'''
{{small|(1917–2002)}} | 25 January 1964 | 29 November 1965 | {{age in years and days|1964|1|25|1965|11|29}} | [[Dahomeyan Democratic Party|PDD]] |- ! style="background:{{Military Rule/meta/color}}" | ! 3 | | '''[[Christophe Soglo]]'''
{{small|(1909–1983)}} | 29 November 1965 | 21 December 1967 | {{age in years and days|1965|11|29|1967|12|21}} | [[Benin Armed Forces|Military]] |- ! style="background:{{Military Rule/meta/color}}" | ! 4 | | '''[[Maurice Kouandété]]'''
{{small|(1932–2003)}} | 21 December 1967 | 17 July 1968 | {{age in years and days|1967|12|21|1968|7|17}} | [[Benin Armed Forces|Military]] |- | colspan=8 align=center|''Post Abolished (17 July 1968–30 November 1975)'' |} ===[[Benin|Republic of Benin]]=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; border:1px #aaf solid; width:90%;" |- !rowspan="2" colspan="2" | {{Abbr|No.|Number}} !rowspan="2" style="width:70px;" | Portrait !rowspan="2" | Name
{{small|(Birth–Death)}} !colspan="3" | Term of Office !rowspan="2" | Political Party |- !{{small|Took Office}} !{{small|Left Office}} !{{small|Time in Office}} |-style="background:#e6e6aa;" ! style="background:{{Independent (politician)/meta/color}}" | ! — | [[File:Nicéphore Soglo - mars 2012.jpg|70px]] | '''[[Nicéphore Soglo]]'''
{{small|(1934–)}} | 12 March 1990 | 4 April 1991 | {{age in years and days|1990|3|12|1991|4|4}} | [[Independent politician|Independent]] |- | colspan=8 align=center|''Post Abolished (4 April 1991–9 April 1996)'' |- ! style="background:#156CC4" | ! 5 | [[File:Noimage.png|70px]] | '''[[Adrien Houngbédji]]'''
{{small|(1942–)}} | 9 April 1996 | 14 May 1998 | {{age in years and days|1996|4|9|1998|5|14}} | [[Democratic Renewal Party (Benin)|PRD]] |- | colspan=8 align=center|''Post Abolished (14 May 1998–28 May 2011)'' |- ! style="background:{{Cowry Forces for an Emerging Benin/meta/color}}" | ! 6 | [[File:Noimage.png|70px]] | '''[[Pascal Koupaki]]'''
{{small|(1951–)}} | 28 May 2011 | 11 August 2013 | {{age in years and days|2011|5|28|2013|8|11}} | [[Cowry Forces for an Emerging Benin|FCBE]] |- | colspan=8 align=center|''Post Abolished (11 August 2013–18 June 2015)'' |- ! style="background:{{Cowry Forces for an Emerging Benin/meta/color}}" | ! 7 | [[File:Lionel Zinsou.jpg|70px]] | '''[[Lionel Zinsou]]'''
{{small|(1953–)}} | 18 June 2015 | 6 April 2016 | {{age in years and days|2015|6|18|2016|4|6}} | [[Cowry Forces for an Emerging Benin|FCBE]] |- | colspan=8 align=center|''Post Abolished (6 April 2016–present)'' |} ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==See also== *[[Republic of Dahomey|Dahomey]] *[[Benin]] **[[List of Presidents of Benin]] **[[List of colonial governors of Dahomey]] *[[Lists of office-holders]] ==External links== *[http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Benin.html World Statesmen (Benin)] {{Benin topics}} {{Heads of state and government of African states}} [[Category:Prime Ministers of Benin|*]] [[Category:Lists of prime ministers|Benin]] [[Category:Benin-related lists|Prime Ministers]]

page.title: List of Stockholm School of Economics people

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=June 2010}} <!-- PLEASE DO NOT ADD NON NOTABLE PEOPLE TO THIS LIST --> <!-- This list is far from complete, please help add relevant notable people. --> <!-- this site will provide some people: http://sv.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lista_över_alumner_från_Handelshögskolan_i_Stockholm -->
The '''list of Stockholm School of Economics alumni''' includes notable graduates, professors and administrators affiliated with [[Stockholm School of Economics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hhs.se/en/Outreach/alumni/|title=Alumni and Friends|website=www.hhs.se|access-date=2017-12-11}}</ref>
== Business == * [[Jan Carlzon]], former CEO of [[SAS Group]] * [[Fredrik Eklund]], real estate broker * [[Erik Engstrom]], CEO of [[Reed Elsevier]] * [[Christer Gardell]], CEO of [[AB Custos]] and founder of [[Cevian Capital]] * [[Reinhold Geijer]], head of the Nordic Region for [[The Royal Bank of Scotland]] * [[Per Olof Loof]], CEO of [[KEMET Corporation]] * [[Ruben Rausing]], founder of liquid food packaging company [[Tetra Pak]] * [[Charlotte Strömberg]], CEO Nordic branch of [[JLL (company)|JLL]] * [[Oscar Swartz]], founder of [[Internet service provider]] [[Bahnhof]]
== Economics == * [[Eli Heckscher]], [[political economist]], [[economic historian]] and co-developer of the [[Heckscher–Ohlin model]] * [[Gunnar Myrdal]], [[Nobel laureate]] economist, sociologist, and politician * [[Bertil Ohlin]], Nobel laureate economist, politician and co-developer of the Heckscher–Ohlin model
== Politics == * [[Margaretha af Ugglas]], former [[Moderate Party]] politician and previous [[Minister of Foreign Affairs]] * [[Magdalena Andersson (Social Democrat)|Magdalena Andersson]], spokesperson on economic politics for the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party]] * [[Erik Åsbrink]], politician of the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party]] and former [[Minister of Finance]] * [[Klas Eklund]], economist and writer * [[Ali Esbati]], former chairman of [[Young Left (Sweden)|Young Left]], member of the [[Riksdag|Swedish Parliament]] for [[Vänsterpartiet]] * [[Stefan Ingves]], Governor of [[Sveriges Riksbank]] * [[Olof Johansson]], former leader of the [[Centre Party (Sweden)|Swedish Centre Party]] * [[Erik Lakomaa]], [[political consultant]] and strategist for the no-campaign in the Swedish 2003 [[Euro]] referendum * [[Mikael Odenberg]], politician of the [[Moderate Party]]; former [[Minister of Defence]] * [[Per Westerberg]], former [[Speaker of the Riksdag]]
== Culture and entertainment == * [[Alexander Bard]], musician and writer * [[Jonas Hassen Khemiri]], novelist and playwright * [[Kristian Luuk]], comedian and television host * [[Niklas Modig]], best-selling author and management speaker<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hhs.se/sv/personsida/?personId=11341033|title=Personsida|website=www.hhs.se|access-date=2017-12-11}}</ref> * [[Lars Nittve]], art critic and director of [[Moderna Museet]] * [[Johan Renck]], director and musician * [[Max Tegmark]], physicist and author
== Academics == * [[Evert Gummesson]], professor of marketing and management
== See also == *[[:Category:Stockholm School of Economics alumni]] *[[:Category:Stockholm School of Economics faculty]]
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Stockholm School Of Economics People}} [[Category:Stockholm School of Economics]] [[Category:Stockholm-related lists|Stockholm School of Economics]] [[Category:Lists of people by university or college in Sweden|Stockholm]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lists of airports in Oceania]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{GeoGroupTemplate}} [[File:Flag of Palau.svg|100px]] This is a '''list of [[airport]]s in [[Palau]]''', sorted by location. The Republic of Palau ({{lang-pau|Beluu er a Belau}}), is an [[island nation]] in the [[Pacific Ocean]]. It emerged from [[United Nations]] [[United Nations Trusteeship Council|trusteeship]] (administered by the [[United States]]) in 1994. It is one of the [[List of countries by date of independence|world's youngest]] and smallest [[sovereign states]]. In English, the name is sometimes spelled Belau in accordance with the native pronunciation. __TOC__ == Airports == Airport names shown in '''bold''' indicate the airport has scheduled service on commercial airlines. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- valign=baseline ! style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" | [[States of Palau|State]] ! style="text-align:left; white-space:nowrap;" | [[List of islands in Palau|Island]] ! style="text-align:left;" | [[ICAO location indicator|ICAO]] !
