page.title: List of birds of Wallis and Futuna

revision.comment: Attribution: Bird descriptions were copied from their respective articles. Please see the history of those pages for full attribution.
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=December 2014}} This is a '''list of the bird species recorded in Wallis and Futuna'''. The avifauna of [[Wallis and Futuna]] include a total of 39 species, of which two have been [[Introduced species|introduced]] by humans and three are rare or accidental. Two species are globally threatened.
This list's [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] treatment (designation and sequence of orders, families and species) and nomenclature (common and scientific names) follow the conventions of ''[[The Clements Checklist of Birds of the World]]'', 6th edition. The family accounts at the beginning of each heading reflect this taxonomy, as do the species counts found in each family account. Introduced and accidental species are included in the total counts for Wallis and Futuna.
The following tags have been used to highlight several categories. Not all species fall into one of these categories. Those that do not are commonly occurring native species.
*(A) '''[[Vagrancy (biology)|Accidental]]''' - a species that rarely or accidentally occurs in Wallis and Futuna *(I) '''[[Introduced species|Introduced]]''' - a species introduced to Wallis and Futuna as a consequence, direct or indirect, of human actions
__NOTOC__ {| class="toccolours" style="margin:0 auto; width:55em; clear:both;" !Table of contents |- | class="wikitable nowraplinks" style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; text-align:center;"| '''Non-passerines''': [[#Shearwaters and petrels|Shearwaters and petrels]] • [[#Tropicbirds|Tropicbirds]] • [[#Boobies and gannets|Boobies and gannets]] • [[#Frigatebirds|Frigatebirds]] • [[#Bitterns, herons and egrets|Bitterns, herons and egrets]] • [[#Ducks, geese and swans|Ducks, geese and swans]] • [[#Hawks, kites and eagles|Hawks, kites and eagles]] • [[#Rails, crakes, gallinules and coots|Rails, crakes, gallinules and coots]] • [[#Plovers and lapwings|Plovers and lapwings]] • [[#Sandpipers and allies|Sandpipers and allies]] • [[#Gulls, terns, and skimmers|Gulls, terns, and skimmers]] • [[#Pigeons and doves|Pigeons and doves]] • [[#Parrots and allies|Parrots and allies]] • [[#Cuckoos and anis|Cuckoos and anis]] • [[#Barn owls|Barn owls]] • [[#Swifts|Swifts]] • [[#Kingfishers|Kingfishers]] |- | class="wikitable nowraplinks" style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; text-align:center;"| '''Passerines''': [[#Cuckooshrikes|Cuckooshrikes]] • [[#Monarch flycatchers|Monarch flycatchers]] • [[#Honeyeaters|Honeyeaters]] • [[#Starlings|Starlings]] |- | style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; text-align:center;"| '''[[#See also|See also]]'''{{nbsp|7}} '''[[#References|References]]''' |}
==Shearwaters and petrels== '''Order''': [[Procellariiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Procellariidae]]
The procellariids are the main group of medium-sized "true petrels", characterised by united nostrils with medium septum and a long outer functional primary.
*[[Herald petrel]], ''Pterodroma heraldica'' (A) *[[Mottled petrel]], ''Pterodroma inexpectata'' (A) *[[Black-winged petrel]], ''Pterodroma nigripennis'' *[[Gould's petrel]], ''Pterodroma leucoptera'' (A) *[[Collared petrel]], ''Pterodroma brevipes'' *[[Tahiti petrel]], ''Pseudobulweria rostrata'' (A) *[[Wedge-tailed shearwater]], ''Ardenna pacifica]]'' *[[Buller's shearwater]], ''Ardenna bulleri'' *[[Sooty shearwater]], ''Ardenna grisea'' *[[Newell's shearwater]], ''Puffinus newelli'' (A) *[[Tropical shearwater]], ''Puffinus bailloni''
==Tropicbirds== '''Order''': [[Phaethontiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Phaethontidae]]
[[Tropicbird]]s are slender white birds of tropical oceans, with exceptionally long central tail feathers. Their heads and long wings have black markings.
*[[Red-tailed tropicbird]], ''Phaethon rubricauda'' *[[White-tailed tropicbird]], ''Phaethon lepturus''
==Boobies and gannets== '''Order''': [[Suliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Sulidae]]
The sulids comprise the [[gannet]]s and [[Booby|boobies]]. Both groups are medium to large coastal seabirds that plunge-dive for fish.
*[[Red-footed booby]], ''Sula sula'' *[[Brown booby]], ''Sula leucogaster''
==Frigatebirds== '''Order''': [[Suliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Fregatidae]]
[[Frigatebird]]s are large seabirds usually found over tropical oceans. They are large, black and white or completely black, with long wings and deeply forked tails. The males have coloured inflatable throat pouches. They do not swim or walk and cannot take off from a flat surface. Having the largest wingspan-to-body-weight ratio of any bird, they are essentially aerial, able to stay aloft for more than a week.
*[[Great frigatebird]], ''Fregata minor'' (A) *[[Lesser frigatebird]], ''Fregata ariel''
==Bitterns, herons and egrets== '''Order''': [[Pelecaniformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Ardeidae]]
The family Ardeidae contains the [[bittern]]s, [[heron]]s and [[egret]]s. Herons and egrets are medium to large wading birds with long necks and legs. Bitterns tend to be shorter necked and more wary. Members of Ardeidae fly with their necks retracted, unlike other long-necked birds such as storks, ibises and spoonbills.
*[[Pacific reef heron]], ''Egretta sacra''
==Ducks, geese and swans== '''Order''': [[Anseriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Anatidae]]
Anatidae includes the [[duck]]s and most duck-like waterfowl, such as [[Goose|geese]] and [[swan]]s. These birds are adapted to an aquatic existence with webbed feet, flattened bills, and feathers that are excellent at shedding water due to an oily coating.
*[[Pacific black duck]], ''Anas superciliosa''
==Hawks, kites and eagles== '''Order''': [[Accipitriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Accipitridae]]
Accipitridae is a family of birds of prey, which includes [[hawk]]s, [[eagle]]s, [[Kite (bird)|kites]], [[Harrier (bird)|harriers]] and [[Old World vulture]]s. These birds have powerful hooked beaks for tearing flesh from their prey, strong legs, powerful talons and keen eyesight.
*[[Swamp harrier]], ''Circus approximans'' (A)
==Rails, crakes, gallinules and coots== '''Order''': [[Gruiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Rallidae]]
Rallidae is a large family of small to medium-sized birds which includes the [[Rail (bird)|rails]], [[crake]]s, [[coot]]s and [[gallinule]]s. Typically they inhabit dense vegetation in damp environments near lakes, swamps or rivers. In general they are shy and secretive birds, making them difficult to observe. Most species have strong legs and long toes which are well adapted to soft uneven surfaces. They tend to have short, rounded wings and to be weak fliers.
*[[Buff-banded rail]], ''Gallirallus philippensis'' *[[Australasian swamphen]], ''Porphyrio melanotus''
==Plovers and lapwings== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Charadriidae]]
The family Charadriidae includes the [[plover]]s, [[dotterel]]s and [[lapwing]]s. They are small to medium-sized birds with compact bodies, short, thick necks and long, usually pointed, wings. They are found in open country worldwide, mostly in habitats near water.
*[[Pacific golden plover]], ''Pluvialis fulva''
==Sandpipers and allies== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Scolopacidae]]
Scolopacidae is a large diverse family of small to medium-sized shorebirds including the [[sandpiper]]s, [[curlew]]s, [[godwit]]s, [[Tringa|shanks]], [[tattler (bird)|tattler]]s, [[woodcock]]s, [[snipe]]s, [[dowitcher]]s and [[phalarope]]s. The majority of these species eat small invertebrates picked out of the mud or soil. Variation in length of legs and bills enables multiple species to feed in the same habitat, particularly on the coast, without direct competition for food.
*[[Bar-tailed godwit]], ''Limosa lapponica'' *[[Whimbrel]], ''Numenius phaeopus'' *[[Bristle-thighed curlew]], ''Numenius tahitiensis'' *[[Wandering tattler]], ''Tringa incana'' *[[Ruddy turnstone]], ''Arenaria interpres''
==Gulls, terns, and skimmers== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Laridae]]
Laridae is a family of medium to large seabirds, the [[gull]]s, [[tern]]s, and [[skimmer]]s. Gulls are typically grey or white, often with black markings on the head or wings. They have stout, longish bills and webbed feet. Terns are a group of generally medium to large seabirds typically with grey or white plumage, often with black markings on the head. Most terns hunt fish by diving but some pick insects off the surface of fresh water. Terns are generally long-lived birds, with several species known to live in excess of 30 years.
*[[Greater crested tern]], ''Thalasseus bergii'' (A) *[[Black-naped tern]], ''Sterna sumatrana'' *[[Bridled tern]], ''Onychoprion anaethetus'' *[[Black noddy]], ''Anous minutus'' *[[Brown noddy]], ''Anous stolidus'' *[[White tern]], ''Gygis alba''
==Pigeons and doves== '''Order''': [[Columbiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Columbidae]]
[[Pigeon]]s and [[dove]]s are stout-bodied birds with short necks and short slender bills with a fleshy [[cere]].
*[[Rock pigeon]], ''Columba livia'' (I) *[[Friendly ground dove]], ''Gallicolumba stairi'' *[[Crimson-crowned fruit dove]], ''Ptilinopus porphyraceus'' *[[Pacific imperial pigeon]], ''Ducula pacifica''
==Parrots and allies== '''Order''': [[Psittaciformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Psittaculidae]]
*[[Blue-crowned lorikeet]], ''Vini australis''
==Cuckoos and anis== '''Order''': [[Cuculiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Cuculidae]]
The family Cuculidae includes [[cuckoo]]s, [[Geococcyx|roadrunner]]s and [[Ani (bird)|anis]]. These birds are of variable size with slender bodies, long tails and strong legs.
*[[Long-tailed koel]], ''Eudynamys taitensis''
==Barn owls== '''Order''': [[Strigiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Tytonidae]]
[[Barn owl]]s are medium to large owls with large heads and characteristic heart-shaped faces. They have long strong legs with powerful talons.
*[[Barn owl]], ''Tyto alba''
==Swifts== '''Order''': [[Apodiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Apodidae]]
[[Swift]]s are small birds which spend the majority of their lives flying. These birds have very short legs and never settle voluntarily on the ground, perching instead only on vertical surfaces. Many swifts have long swept-back wings which resemble a crescent or boomerang.
*[[White-rumped swiftlet]], ''Aerodramus spodiopygius''
==Kingfishers== '''Order''': [[Coraciiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Alcedinidae]]
Kingfishers are medium-sized birds with large heads, long pointed bills, short legs and stubby tails.
*[[Pacific kingfisher]], ''Todirhamphus sacer'' *[[Sacred kingfisher]], ''Todirhamphus sanctus''
==Cuckooshrikes== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Campephagidae]]
The cuckooshrikes are small to medium-sized passerine birds. They are predominantly greyish with white and black, although some species are brightly coloured.
*[[Polynesian triller]], ''Lalage maculosa''
==Monarch flycatchers== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Monarchidae]]
The monarch flycatchers are small to medium-sized insectivorous passerines which hunt by flycatching.
*[[Fiji shrikebill]], ''Clytorhynchus vitiensis''
==Honeyeaters== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Meliphagidae]]
The honeyeaters are a large and diverse family of small to medium-sized birds most common in Australia and New Guinea. They are nectar feeders and closely resemble other nectar-feeding passerines.
*[[Wattled honeyeater]], ''Foulehaio carunculata''
==Starlings== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Sturnidae]]
Starlings are small to medium-sized passerine birds. Their flight is strong and direct and they are very gregarious. Their preferred habitat is fairly open country. They eat insects and fruit. Plumage is typically dark with a metallic sheen.
*[[Polynesian starling]], ''Aplonis tabuensis'' *[[Common myna]], ''Acridotheres tristis'' (I)
==See also== *[[List of birds]] *[[Lists of birds by region]]
==References== *{{cite web | last = Lepage | first = Denis | authorlink = | coauthors = | year = | url = http://www.bsc-eoc.org/avibase/avibase.jsp?region=wf&pg=checklist&list=clements | title = Checklist of birds of Wallis and Futuna | format = | work = Bird Checklists of the World | publisher = Avibase | accessdate = 30 April 2007 }} *{{cite book | title=Birds of the World: a Checklist | first= James F. | last = Clements | publisher = Cornell University Press | year = 2000 | isbn = 0-934797-16-1 | page = 880 }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List of birds Of Wallis And Futuna}} [[Category:Environment of Wallis and Futuna]] [[Category:Lists of birds by country|Wallis and Futuna]] [[Category:Wallis and Futuna-related lists|Birds]] [[Category:Oceania ecozone fauna|Wallis and Futuna birds]] [[Category:Birds of Polynesia]]

{{Infobox Political post |post = President |body = Burkina Faso |native_name = ''{{lang|fr|Président du Burkina Faso}}'' |insignia = Presidential Standard of Burkina Faso.svg |insigniasize = 125px |insigniacaption = Presidential Standard |nativename = |image = Roch Marc Christian Kaboré.jpg |imagesize = 165px |incumbent = [[Roch Marc Christian Kaboré]] |incumbentsince = 29 December 2015 |style = |residence = Kossyam Palace |appointer = |termlength = 5 years |formation = 5 August 1960 |succession = |inaugural = [[Maurice Yaméogo]] |deputy = |salary = |website = }} {{Politics of Burkina Faso}} This is a '''list of [[Head of state|heads of state]] of [[Burkina Faso]]''' since the [[Republic of Upper Volta]] gained independence from [[France]] in 1960 to the present day. A total of eight people have served as head of state of Upper Volta/Burkina Faso (not counting three Transitional Heads of State/Presidents and one Acting President in rebellion). The current head of state of Burkina Faso is the President of the Republic [[Roch Marc Christian Kaboré]], since 29 December 2015. ==Titles== * '''1960–1980''': President of the Republic * '''1980–1982''': President of Military Committee of Recovery for National Progress * '''1982''': Chairman of Provisional Committee of Popular Salvation * '''1982–1983''': Head of State * '''1983–1987''': Chairman of National Revolutionary Council and Head of State * '''1987–1991''': President of [[Popular Front (Burkina Faso)|Popular Front]] and Head of State * '''1991–2014''': President of the Republic * '''2015''': Chairman of [[National Council for Democracy]] * '''2015–present''': President of the Republic ==Key== ;''Political parties'' *{{legend|Green|[[African Democratic Rally (Burkina Faso)|Voltaic Democratic Union – African Democratic Rally]] (UDV–RDA)|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|Red|[[Popular Front (Burkina Faso)|Popular Front]] (FP) / [[Organization for Popular Democracy – Labour Movement]] (ODP–MT) / [[Congress for Democracy and Progress]] (CDP)|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|Orange|[[People's Movement for Progress]] (MPP)|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ;''Other factions'' *{{legend|{{Military Rule/meta/color}}|[[Military of Burkina Faso|Military]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|{{Independent (politician)/meta/color}}|[[Independent politician|Independent]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ;''Status'' *{{legend|#E6E6AA|Transitional Head of State/President|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} *{{legend|#C0C0C0|Acting President in rebellion|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} ==List== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:85%;text-align:center" !rowspan=2|№ !rowspan=2|Name

page.title: List of homonymous states and regions

revision.text:
The following is a '''list of [[Homonym|homonymous]] states and regions'''.
==National entities and subnational entities== :''This is a list of national entities bearing the same or similar names as subnational entities. For a general list of divided regions bearing the same or similar names, see [[Divided regions]].'' * [[Afghanistan]] (country) and [[Afghania]] (alternative name for the [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] [[Administrative units of Pakistan|province in Pakistan]]) * [[Azerbaijan]] (country) and [[Azerbaijan (Iran)|Azerbaijan]] (historical region of Iran) * [[East Timor]] (country) and [[West Timor]] (part of the [[East Nusa Tenggara]] [[Provinces of Indonesia|province of Indonesia]]) * [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] (country) and [[Georgia (U.S. state)]] * [[Guatemala]] (country) and [[Guatemala Department]] ([[Departments of Guatemala|department of Guatemala]]) * [[Luxembourg]] (country) and [[Luxembourg (Belgium)|Luxembourg]] ([[Provinces of Belgium|province of Belgium]]) * [[Moldova]] (country) and [[Moldavia|Moldova/Moldavia]] (historical region of Romania) * [[Panama]] (country) and [[Panamá Province]] in Panama * [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] (country) and [[Macedonia (Greece)|Macedonia]] ([[Geographic regions of Greece|historical-geographic region of Greece]]); see [[Macedonia (terminology)]] * Originally, ''[[Belgica]]'' was one of the Latin names of [[the Netherlands]] and the French ''Belgique'' was used as a translation of the same country's name. However, after the Southern Netherlands became independent as ''Belgium'', it became common to refer to the Netherlands in French as ''Pays-Bas'' instead.
==Subnational entities== :''This is a list of subnational entities that bear the same or similar names. For a list of divided subnational entities<!--e.g., Fujian Province, People's Republic of China and Fujian Province, Republic of China-->, see [[Divided regions]].'' * [[Baden]] (a historical territory of Germany) and [[Baden District, Aargau|Baden District]] (a district in [[Switzerland]]) * [[Brittany]] (a [[cultural region]] in France) and [[Brittany (administrative region)|Brittany]] (an [[Regions of France|administrative region]] in France); Brittany (the cultural region) has also been referred to as ''Less'', ''Lesser'' or ''Little Britain'' (as opposed to [[Great Britain]]) * [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], a region and autonomous community of northwestern Spain and [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]], a historical region in southeastern Poland and western Ukraine * [[Munster]] (a [[Provinces of Ireland|province]] and ancient [[List of kings of Munster|sub-national kingdom]] in [[Ireland]]) and [[Münster]] (a city in [[Germany]]) * [[New Caledonia]], a French island in the South Pacific, and [[New Caledonia (Canada)|New Caledonia]], a former colony in what is now [[British Columbia]], Canada * [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]] ([[States of Brazil|state of Brazil]]) and [[Paraná, Entre Ríos|Paraná]] (city in Argentina)
==Ancient regions== :''This is a list of ancient regions that bear the same or similar names. For a list of formerly divided regions, see [[Divided regions#Formerly divided regions|Formerly divided regions]].'' * [[Albania]], a country in the Balkans, and [[Caucasian Albania|Albania]], an ancient land in the [[Caucasus]], mostly in modern [[Azerbaijan]] * [[Galatia|Galatia (Anatolia)]] and [[Galatia (Europe)]] * [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberia]] (Iberian Peninsula), a peninsula in western Europe occupied by Spain and Portugal, and [[Caucasian Iberia|Iberia]] in the [[Caucasus]] region (now mainly in [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]])
==See also== * [[Albania (placename)]] * [[Dardania (disambiguation)|Dardania]] * [[Thrace (disambiguation)]]
[[Category:Lists of country names|Homonym]] [[Category:Regions|*Homonymous]]

{{refimprove|date=January 2013}} {{Legislature}} This is a '''list of legislatures by country'''. A "legislature" is the generic name for the National [[parliamentary system|parliaments]] and [[congressional system|congresses]] that act as a plenary general [[deliberative assembly|assembly]] of [[representative democracy|representatives]] and that have the power to [[legislature|legislate]]. All entities included in the [[list of countries]] are included in this list. ==Names of legislatures== The legislatures are listed with their names in English and the name in the (most-used) native language of the country (or the official name in the second-most used native language in cases where English is the majority "native" language) ==List of legislatures== ===Supranational [[File:Carl spitteler 1905.jpg|thumb|Carl Spitteler, writer and Nobel laureate, was born in Lucerne in 1845]]
[[Lucerne]] in central [[Switzerland]] is the capital of the [[canton of Lucerne]] and part of the [[Lucerne (district)|district of Lucerne]]. With a population of about 81,057 people ({{As of|2013|lc=y}}),<ref name=Lustat2013WBAbs>{{cite web |title=Ständige Wohnbevölkerung nach Altersgruppen Ende 2013 – Gemeinden Kanton Luzern – Männer und Frauen - Absolut |url=http://www2.lustat.ch/download/lustat_new/kt/0003/w012_002t_kt0003_gd_d_2013_001_008.html |publisher=lustat - Statistik Luzern, Kanton Luzern |date=18 August 2014 |type=Database excerpt |website=www.lustat.ch |language=German |accessdate=2015-02-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209233946/http://www2.lustat.ch/download/lustat_new/kt/0003/w012_002t_kt0003_gd_d_2013_001_008.html |archivedate=9 February 2015 |df= }}</ref> it is the most populous town in [[Central Switzerland]]. Notable people associated with Lucerne include:
== to 1700 == * [[Petermann von Gundoldingen]] (? -1386), Schultheiss, participant in the battle near Sempach {{fact|date=April 2017}} * [[Melchior Russ]] (c. 1450-1499), historian {{fact|date=April 2017}} * [[Oswald Myconius]] (1488-1552), reformer <ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GGpyDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA198#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=198|title=A Companion to the Swiss Reformation|author=Amy Nelson Burnett, Emidio Campi|publisher=BRILL|date= 8 Jul 2016}}</ref> * [[Johann Baptist Cysat]] (1585-1657), mathematician and astronomer <ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=t-BF1CHkc50C&pg=PA267#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=267|title=Biographical Encyclopedia of Astronomers|author=Virginia Trimble, et al|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|date= 18 Sep 2007}}</ref>
== 1701 to 1850 ==
* [[Anna Maria Rüttimann-Meyer von Schauensee]] (1772-1856) {{fact|date=April 2017}} * [[Josef Martin Knüsel]] (1813-1889), politician and jurist {{fact|date=April 2017}} * [[Robert Zünd]] (1826-1909), painter <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sammlungonline.kunstmuseumluzern.ch/eMP/eMuseumPlus?service=ExternalInterface&siteId=1&module=artist&objectId=955&viewType=detailView&lang=en|work=sammlungonline.kunstmuseumluzern.ch|title=Robert Zund}}</ref> * [[Carl Spitteler]] (1845-1924), writer and Nobel laureate (died in Lucerne) <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Carl-Spitteler|title=Carl-Spitteler|work=britannica.com}}</ref> * [[Josef Anton Schobinger]] (1849-1911), politician and builder <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D4200.php|title=Schobinger, Josef Anton|work=hls-dhs-dss.ch}}</ref>
== 1851 to 1900 == {{unsourced section|date=April 2017}} *[[Siegfried Wagner]] (1869-1930), German composer, librettist and conductor *[[Fritz Brun]] (1878-1959), composer and conductor *[[Ernst Hodel junior]] (1881-1955), painter *[[Robert Wuellner]] (1885-1966), actor, director and filmproducer
==1901 to 1950== {{unsourced section|date=April 2017}} *[[Edgar Gretener]] (1902-1958), electrical engineer *[[Max von Moos]] (1903-1979), painter and graphic artist *[[Thelma Furness, Viscountess Furness]] (1904-1970), American socialite *[[Gloria Morgan-Vanderbilt]] (1904-1965), American socialite *[[Hans Urs von Balthasar]] (1905-1988), theologian *[[Herbert Ernst Groh]] (1906-1982), tenor *[[Franz Riedweg]] (1907-2005), doctor and SS Obersturmbannführer *[[Hans Erni]] (1909-2015), painter, graphic artist and sculptor *Robert Pilchowski ([[:de:Robert Pilchowski|de]]) (1909-1990), writer *[[Josef-Maria Jauch]] (1914-1974), theoretical physicist *[[Anton Muheim]] (1916-2016), Social Democrat politician, President of the National Council *[[Toni Hagen]] (1917-2003), geologist *[[Alphons Egli]] (1924-2016), politician *[[Rolf Brem]] (1926-2014), sculptor, draftsman and graphic artist *[[Caspar Diethelm]] (1926-1997), composer *[[André Thomkins]] (1930-1985), painter, draftsman and poet *[[Armin Jordan]] (1932-2006), conductor *[[Emil Steinberger (actor)]] (born 1933), cabaret artist, writer, director and actor *[[Edith Mathis]] (born 1938), soprano and university professor *[[Stanislaus von Moos]] (born 1940), art historian and architectural theorist *[[Karl Odermatt]] (born 1942), footballer *[[Michael Pieper]] (born 1946), billionaire businessman<ref>{{cite web |title=Forbes profile: Michael Pieper |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/michael-pieper/ |website=Forbes |accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref> *[[Kurt Müller (footballer)]] (born 1948), footballer *[[Fredy Studer]] (born 1948), drummer *[[Peter Bichsel]], (born 1935), writer *[[Peter von Matt]], (born 1937), philologist, specialist for German studies, author
==1950 to today== *[[Urs Leimgruber]] (born 1952), saxophonist {{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Stephan Klapproth]], (born 1958), journalist and television presenter {{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Jolanda Egger]] (born 1960), actress, beauty queen, model and racing driver {{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Heidi Brunner]] (born 1961), opera singer <ref>{{cite book|title=International Who's Who in Classical Music 2009|page=113|author=Routledge|publisher=Routledge|date= 1 Mar 2009 }}</ref> *[[Thomas Imbach]] (born 1962), filmmaker{{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Hippolyt Kempf]] (born 1965), Olympia gold medal winner (Nordic combined) {{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Rolf Dobelli]] (born 1966), writer and entrepreneur {{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Markus Breitschmid]] (born 1966), architectural theorist and architectural historian {{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Felix Gmür]] (born 1966), theologian and bishop of Basel {{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Andrea Štaka]] (born 1973), director and screenwriter {{fact|date=April 2017}} *[[Claudio Castagnoli]] (born 1980), professional wrestler <ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=KUsJAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA66&lpg=PA66#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=66|title=Historical Dictionary of Wrestling|chapter=John Grasso|publisher= Scarecrow Press|date= 6 Mar 2014}}</ref>

[[File:Plano de Granada 1795.jpeg|thumb|Luis del Mármol Carvajal, "Historia del rebelión y castigo de los moriscos del Reino de Granada". Map of Granada, 1795.]] '''Luis del Marmol Carvajal''' ([[Granada]], [[Spain]], 1520 - [[Velez Malaga]], [[Spain]], 1600) was a Spanish chronicler living many years among the formerly [[Moorish]] [[Granada]] kingdom [[morisco]]'s inhabitants and in the [[North African]] [[Berber people|Berber]] regions at the end of the 15th, and a good part of the 16th century.
He was proficient in [[Hassaniya]] Arabic, Berber [[Tamazight]] and/or the [[Algeria]]n [[Berber language|Berber]] [[Taqbaylit]] language. He was the illegitimate son of a High Justice Officer, Pedro del Marmol, who recognized him as his natural son in 1528. Whether his mother was some sort of slave or personal servant of this High Court Office lawyer, his father, "given" or "bought" after the conquest of [[Granada]], 1492, cannot be confirmed.
It is well known that after the dissolution of the [[Caliph of Córdoba]] in the 11th century, many of the rulers and people from the kingdom of [[Granada]] maintained that their identities were essentially [[Zenata]] Berber. This may explain their settlements and affinity with the [[Merinid]] and after the [[Wattasids]] dynasty, (وطاسيون waṭāsīyūn), ruling [[Fes|Fez]], until, after 1554, the [[Saadi dynasty|Saadi]]´s rulers, (Arabic: سعديون), from [[Tagmadert]], at the [[Draa river]] valley, near [[Tidzi]], near [[Zagora, Morocco|Zagora]], conquered the town.
It is said that for eight years Luis del Marmol was imprisoned in [[Algiers]], and that he returned to [[Spain]] in his mid-thirties after fighting in Italy, Spain and the North African litoral from the Atlantic shores. He spent time moving and visiting places, including Libyan Berber areas. Dates for these adventures are given just around 1554, curiously enough after the conquest of [[Fes|Fez]].
Luis del Mármol y Carvajal's history is a very valuable reference for it covers a period longer by a further 50 years, than that of the other [[Andalusia]]n chronicler, the diplomat and author of [[Description of Africa (1550 book)|Description of Africa]]<ref>Descrittione dell'Africa, Venice edition: 1550. French and Latin editions, 1556.</ref>, known as [[Leo Africanus|Joannes Leo Africanus]], or al-Hasan ibn Muhammad al-Wazzan [[al-Fasi]], (ar: حسن ابن محمد الوزان الفاسي) (c. 1494 – c. 1554?).
==Works published== {{confusing section|date=January 2012}} * ''Descripción general de África, sus guerras y vicisitudes, desde la fundación del mahometismo hasta el año 1571 . Ed. Granada, (1573–1599)''. Apparently based on [[Leo Africanus]] and with additional places and more recent dates.
*''Historia del [sic] rebelión y castigo de los moriscos del Reino de Granada'' . Edición digital: Alicante : Biblioteca Virtual Miguel de Cervantes, 2001. Edición original en el catálogo de la Biblioteca de la Universidad de Alicante . Edición digital a partir de Biblioteca de Autores Españoles : historiadores de sucesos particulares, tomo I, Madrid, M. Rivadeneyra, 1852, pp. 123–365. Localización: Biblioteca General de la Universidad de Alicante. Sig.FL RS/284. See:http://www.cervantesvirtual.com/FichaObra.html?Ref=5286 :
There is a cheap facsimile edition of another contemporary book in which he polemized with the author, albeit it was no printed at the time of the [[morisco´s war]] in the [[Alpujarra]] by [[Diego Hurtado de Mendoza (poet and diplomat)|Diego Hurtado de Mendoza]]: ''GUERRA DE GRANADA'' (FACSIMIL, edition of 1842), de HURTADO DE MENDOZA, DIEGO , 15.0x21.0 cm , 215 pages , softcover, {{ISBN|978-84-9761-157-2}} Nº Edición:1ª ED. FACS. DE 1842 , (2005), reprit facsimile at Valladolid town. This dvent can be dadsted in the period 1568 - 1572. There was a former edition by Sancha, 1797.
There, he mentions a certain Pedro Zapata del Marmol, ''my brother'', "escribano del Consejo de Castilla.
==References== <references /> *http://dialnet.unirioja.es/servlet/extaut?codigo=75827 *http://www.filol.csic.es/departamentos/curricula/cv_garenal.html. A curriculum on the life and work of Spanish Arabis woman Mercedes García-Arenal, born 1950.

{{flagicon|Uruguay}} [[Tabaré Vázquez]] }} '''Mercosur''', officially '''Southern Common Market'''{{lang-es|link=no|Mercado Común del Sur}}, {{lang-pt|Mercado Comum do Sul}}, {{lang-gn|Ñemby Ñemuha}}, ''Southern Common Market'' is a [[South America]]n [[trade bloc]] established by the [[Treaty of Asunción]] in 1991 and [[Protocol of Ouro Preto]] in 1994. Its full members are [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Paraguay]] and [[Uruguay]]. [[Venezuela]] is a full member but has been suspended since December 1, 2016. Associate countries are [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], [[Guyana]], [[Peru]] and [[Suriname]].{{cite web|url=http://dagbladdewest.com/2015/07/20/suriname-en-guyana-officieel-geassocieerd-lid-mercosur/|title=De West - Suriname en Guyana officieel Geassocieerd Lid Mercosur -|date=20 July 2015|publisher=|accessdate=2 December 2016}} [[Observer status|Observer countries]] are [[New Zealand]] and [[Mexico]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mre.gov.ve/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=22996:se-formaliza-adhesion-de-venezuela-al-mercosur-avance-&catid=363:072012-cumbre-mercosur&Itemid=527 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130073004/http://www.mre.gov.ve/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=22996:se-formaliza-adhesion-de-venezuela-al-mercosur-avance-&catid=363:072012-cumbre-mercosur&Itemid=527 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 January 2016 |title=Se formaliza adhesión de Venezuela al Mercosur |publisher=Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de la República Bolivariana de Venezuela |date= |accessdate=22 November 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.brasil.gov.br/governo/2012/12/presidentes-dos-paises-do-mercosul-se-reunem-para-discutir-integracao-do-bloco|title= Presidentes dos países do Mercosul se reúnem para discutir integração do bloco|publisher=Governo do Brasil|date=|accessdate=23 November 2013}} Mercosur's purpose is to promote [[free trade]] and the fluid movement of goods, people, and currency. It currently confines itself to a customs union, in which there is free intra-zone trade and a common trade policy between member countries. The official languages are Spanish, Portuguese, and [[Guarani language|Guarani]].{{cite web |url=http://www.mercosur.int/buscarenmarco.jsp?url=http%3A//200.40.51.218/SAM/GestDoc/PubWeb.nsf/Busqueda%3FOpenAgent%26TextoBusqueda%3Dguarani%26modulo%3DNormativa%26ModuloBusqueda%3DNormativa%26lang%3DESP%20 |title=Buscar |publisher=Mercosur.int |date= |accessdate=2013-12-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225063003/http://www.mercosur.int/buscarenmarco.jsp?url=http%3A%2F%2F200.40.51.218%2FSAM%2FGestDoc%2FPubWeb.nsf%2FBusqueda%3FOpenAgent&TextoBusqueda=guarani&modulo=Normativa&ModuloBusqueda=Normativa&lang=ESP%20 |archivedate=25 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Since its foundation, Mercosur's functions have been updated, amended, and changed many times: it is now a full [[customs union]] and a [[trading bloc]]. Mercosur and the [[Andean Community of Nations]] are customs unions that are components of a continuing process of South American [[economic integration|integration]] connected to the [[Union of South American Nations]] (USAN). == History == ===Founding=== [[File:Sede del Mercosur - Montevideo, Uruguay.jpg|thumb|left|Headquarters of MERCOSUR, Montevideo, Uruguay.]] Mercosur was established in 1991 by the [[Treaty of Asunción]], which was later amended and updated by the 1994 [[Treaty of Ouro Preto]]. Mercosur originated in 1988, when presidents [[Raúl Alfonsín]] of Argentina and [[José Sarney]] of Brazil signed the ''Argentina-Brazil Integration and Economics Cooperation Program'' or '''PICE''' (Portuguese: Programa de Integração e Cooperação Econômica Argentina-Brasil, Spanish: Programa de Integración y Cooperación Económica Argentina-Brasil).{{cite web|url=http://www2.uol.com.br/actasoft/actamercosul/espanhol/tratado_de_integracion.htm |title=Tratado de Integración, Cooperación y Desarrollo entre Brasil y Argentina |publisher=.uol.com.br |date= |accessdate=2013-12-25}} The protocol Number 20 of the program also proposed the [[Gaucho (currency)|Gaucho]] as a currency for regional trade.{{cite journal |last= |first= |date=November 1987 |title=Protocolo No. 20 |trans-title=Protocol Number 20 |url=http://www19.iadb.org/intal/intalcdi/integracion_latinoamericana/documentos/129-Revista_Completa.pdf |language=es |journal=integración latinoamericana |volume=12 |issue=129 |pages=67 |doi= |access-date=2017-07-19 }} The founding of the [[Mercosur Parliament]] was agreed upon at the December 2004 presidential summit. Up to 2010 it was planned to have 18 representatives from each country, regardless of population.{{cite act|url=http://www.mercosur.int/innovaportal/file/1104/1/2005_protocoloparlamentomcs_es.pdf|title=Protocolo Constitutivo del Parlamento del Mercosur|article=24|language=es|access-date=2017-07-19|date=9 de diciembre de 2005}} ===Memberships and suspensions=== ====Suspension of Paraguay==== [[File:Izamiento.jpg|thumb|First lifting headquarters of Mercosur in Montevideo (2001).]] After suspending Paraguay in 2012, the presidents of the Mercosur countries (Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay, and Venezuela) said in July 2013 that they would lift the suspension after the inauguration of Paraguay's newly elected President, Horacio Cartes, on 15 August 2013. However, Paraguay said it would not return to the Mercosur fold as long as Venezuela held its rotating presidency. Venezuela held Mercosur's rotating presidency until July 2014. Paraguay has objected to Venezuela's inclusion in the trading bloc, and says that a new member can only be included after a unanimous vote and argues that such a vote should not have been held while Paraguay was suspended.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-23716472|title=Paraguay's President Horacio Cartes sworn in|work=BBC News}} Foreign Minister [[Eladio Loizaga]] said he would rather deal with Paraguay's neighbours individually at first. "We have pending issues with Argentina, with Uruguay; we have to recompose all that," he said. "Mercosur will be later because our priority are {{sic}} the bilateral relations," he added. ====Bolivian membership status==== On 7 December 2012, Bolivian President [[Evo Morales]] signed a protocol aimed at accession to full membership of the block.{{cite web|url=http://noticias.terra.com.br/mundo/instituto-boliviano-de-comercio-exterior-critica-entrada-do-pais-no-mercosul,0318cb643b58b310VgnCLD200000bbcceb0aRCRD.html|title=Instituto Boliviano de Comércio Exterior critica entrada do país no Mercosul|publisher=Terra.com|date=|accessdate=23 November 2013}} Such a proposal requires review and possible legislative approval.{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/Noticias/Economia_Negocios/0,,MUL35367-9356,00-PETROBRAS+VALE+DEZ+VEZES+O+PIB+DA+BOLIVIA.html|title= Petrobras vale dez vezes o PIB da Bolívia|publisher=Globo.com|date=|accessdate=23 November 2013}} On July 7 of 2015, the heads of Mercosur having decided to accept Bolivia's request to become a full member country, Bolivian president Evo Morales signed the Brasilia protocol. This acted Bolivia's full membership to the Mercosur.{{cite web|url=http://www.mercosur.int/innovaportal/v/6923/2/innova.front/bolivia-ingresa-al-mercosur|title=MERCOSUR - Bolivia ingresa al MERCOSUR|publisher=|accessdate=2 December 2016}} ====Suspension of Venezuela==== [[File:Conferencia- "Integración Latinoamericana y Mercosur" (7402119210).jpg|thumb|left|The Conference of Latin-American Integration]] In August 2016, the presidents of Brazil, Argentina, and Paraguay, while present in Rio de Janeiro for the Olympic Games, met to discuss suspending Venezuela from Mercosur. The three countries were in doubt about whether Venezuela was complying with the union's requirements for full membership, citing [[human rights violations]] among other issues.{{cite web|url=https://www.stratfor.com/analysis/venezuelas-mercosur-membership-peril|title=Venezuela's Mercosur Membership is in Peril|publisher=Stratfor|date=August 8, 2016|accessdate=November 23, 2016}} In fact, Venezuela was rejected from assuming the presidency of Mercosur by those three countries, prompting a dispute that continued in full throttle to the end of the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Argentina-Brazil-Paraguay-Dispute-Venezuela-as-Mercosur-Head--20160804-0021.html|title=Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay Dispute Venezuela as Mercosur Head |publisher=Telesur|date=August 4, 2016|accessdate=November 23, 2016}} On 21 November 2016, Paraguayan Foreign Minister [[Eladio Loizaga]] announced that Venezuela would be suspended in December 2016 after the nation was given a three-month period to reform its laws to abide to Mercosur requirements, with Mercosur noting that "rules governing trade, politics, democracy and human rights" needed to be overhauled in Venezuela.{{cite news|title=Venezuela suspended from Mercosur beginning December|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/venezuela-suspended-mercosur-beginning-december-000548012.html|accessdate=27 November 2016|work=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=21 November 2016}} On 1 December 2016, Venezuela was suspended from Mercosur.{{cite news|title=Mercosur suspends Venezuela for failure to follow rules|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2016/South-American-nations-say-they-have-suspended-Venezuela-from-the-Mercosur-trade-group-over-its-failure-to-comply-with-its-commitments-when-it-joined-the-group-in-2012/id-d6c987ac4ca84a1ebe5497d4169c6d0e|accessdate=2 December 2016|work=[[Associated Press]]|date=2 December 2016}} == Member states == {{See also|Member states of Mercosur}} [[File:Mercosur.png|thumb|Dark blue: Full members
Grey blue: Associated members
Blue: Observer members]] Mercosur is composed of 5 [[sovereign state|sovereign]] member states: Argentina; Brazil; Paraguay; Uruguay and Venezuela (suspended since December, 2016); and a state in process of incorporation, Bolivia (since July 17, 2015){{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/brazil-mercosur-bolivia-idUSE5N0V801V20150717|title=Bolivia to join Mercosur as full member - Rousseff|date=17 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 December 2016|via=Reuters}} Following the [[Impeachment of Fernando Lugo|impeachment of President Fernando Lugo]] by the Paraguayan Senate, this country was suspended from Mercosur, and the admittance of Venezuela as a full member became effective on 31 July 2012. Venezuela had four years to fully adapt to the trade bloc regulations{{cite web|url=http://www.telesurtv.net/articulos/2012/07/31/venezuela-tendra-cuatro-anos-para-adaptarse-a-normativa-comercial-del-mercosur-5443.html|title=Venezuela tendrá cuatro años para adaptarse a normativa comercial del Mercosur|work=Telesur|date=31 July 2012}} and failed to do so, with the nation being suspended from Mercosur on 1 December 2016. Directly subordinated to the Common Market Group, the Work Subgroups draw up the minutes of the decisions to submit for the consideration of the Council, and study specific Mercosur concerns. The work subgroups are: * Commercial matters * Customs matters * Technical standards * Tax and monetary policies relating to trade * Land transport * Sea transport * Industrial and technology policies * Agricultural policy * Energy policy * Coordination of macroeconomic policies * Labor, employment and social security matters Work subgroups are held quarterly, alternating in every member state, in alphabetical order, or at the Common Market Group Administrative Office. Activities are carried out by the Work Subgroups in two stages: preparatory and conclusive. In the preparatory stage, members of the Work Subgroups may request the participation of representatives from the private sector of each member state. The decision-making stage is reserved exclusively for official representatives of the member states. The delegations of representatives from the private sector in the preparatory stage of the Work Subgroup activities will have a maximum of three representatives for each member state directly involved in any of the stages of the production, distribution or consumption process for the products that fall within the scope of the subgroup's activities., == Heads of state == {{center| File:Presidente Macri en el Sillon de Rivadavia (cropped).jpg|{{flagicon|ARG}} '''[[Argentina]]'''

[[Tabaré Vazquez]]
[[President of Uruguay]] }} == Geography == The territory of Mercosur consists of the combined territories of six of the 12 countries of [[South America]] and their population. Including the overseas territories of member states, Mercosur experiences most [[Köppen climate classification|types of climate]] from [[Polar climate|Antarctic]] to [[tropical climate|tropical]], rendering meteorological averages for Mercosur as a whole meaningless. The majority of the population lives in areas with a [[subtropical climate]] (Uruguay, Southern Paraguay, Northeastern Argentina and Southern and Southeastern Brazil), or a tropical climate (Venezuela and Northeastern Brazil). {{wide image|Iguazu Décembre 2007 - Panorama 7.jpg|1000px|
[[Iguazu Falls]] on the border between Argentina and Brazil is an area with [[subtropical climate]] and are one of the [[New7Wonders of Nature|New Seven World Natural Wonders]].
}} == Demographics == {| class="wikitable" |+(Sources{{UN_Population|ref}}{{cite web|url=http://www.listofcountriesoftheworld.com/area-land.html|title=Countries of the world ordered by land area}}) !Country !! Population ({{UN_Population|Year}}) !! Density !! Language |- ![[Brazil]] |style="text-align:right"| {{#expr:{{replace|{{UN_Population|Brazil}}|,||}}/1e6 round 1}} million || 23.1/km² || Portuguese |- ![[Argentina]] |style="text-align:right"| {{#expr:{{replace|{{UN_Population|Argentina}}|,||}}/1e6 round 1}} million || 14.9/km² || Spanish |- ![[Paraguay]] |style="text-align:right"| {{#expr:{{replace|{{UN_Population|Paraguay}}|,||}}/1e6 round 1}} million || 16.4/km² || Spanish and Guaraní |- ![[Uruguay]] |style="text-align:right"| {{#expr:{{replace|{{UN_Population|Uruguay}}|,||}}/1e6 round 1}} million || 24.0/km² || Spanish |- !Total || 261.6 million || --- || --- |} The region is highly urbanized, and the largest cities in Mercosur are the [[global city|global cities]] [[Buenos Aires]], [[Rio de Janeiro]] and [[São Paulo]]. The white population is the majority in Argentina and CLGT and represents around half the population in Brazil. Mestizos form the majority population in Paraguay.{{cite web|url=http://www.infoamerica.org/primera/lb_2011.pdf|title=Informe Latinobarómetro 2011|publisher=[[Latinobarómetro]]|page=58}} All Mercosur nations have significant Native American populations, especially in Paraguay (Guaraní is a national language in the country along with Spanish, and almost all Paraguayans have Guaraní genetic ancestry), Argentina (especially in the country's North-Western, Northern, and Southern provinces), Brazil (in the Northern Amazonian states of the nation, where Native American tribes have vast reservation lands). Along with Paraguay (where it is one of two official languages), sectors of Argentina (Corrientes) speak Guaraní. However, the Mercosur does not provide all, or even most, services in Guaraní. The official website, almost all official summits are only held in Spanish and Portuguese. File:MarginalPinheiros.jpg|{{flagicon|Brazil}} [[São Paulo]]. File:High-rises of Puerto Madero (40022145164).jpg|{{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Buenos Aires]]. File:World Trade Center Montevideo.jpg|{{flagicon|Uruguay}} [[Montevideo]]. File:Asunción Business Center.jpg|{{flagicon|Paraguay}} [[Asuncion]]. == Merchandise trade == Intra-Mercosur merchandise trade (excluding Venezuela) grew from US$10 billion at the inception of the trade bloc in 1991,{{cite web|url=http://www.fundacionege.org/publicaciones/semanario/2011/06/12/Seccion1.html|title=El Mercosur hoy, a 20 años de su constitución|publisher=Fundación EGE|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304033605/http://www.fundacionege.org/publicaciones/semanario/2011/06/12/Seccion1.html|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} to US$88 billion in 2010; Brazil and Argentina each accounted for 43% of this total. The trade balance within the bloc has historically been tilted toward Brazil, which recorded an intra-Mercosur balance of over US$5 billion in 2010. {{cite web|url=http://www.diariobae.com/diario/2012/07/31/15462-entra-venezuela-al-mercosur-mas-fortaleza-en-energia-y-alimentos.html |title=Entra Venezuela al Mercosur |work=BAE |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508234931/http://www.diariobae.com/diario/2012/07/31/15462-entra-venezuela-al-mercosur-mas-fortaleza-en-energia-y-alimentos.html |archivedate=8 May 2013 |df= }} Trade within Mercosur amounted to only 16% of the four countries' total merchandise trade in 2010, however; trade with the European Union (20%), China (14%), and the United States (11%) was of comparable importance. Exports from the bloc are highly diversified, and include a variety of agricultural, industrial, and energy goods. Merchandise trade with the rest of the world in 2010 resulted in a surplus for Mercosur of nearly US$7 billion; [[trade in services]], however, was in deficit by over US$28 billion. The EU and China maintained a nearly balanced merchandise trade with Mercosur in 2010, while the United States reaped a surplus of over US$14 billion; Mercosur, in turn, earned significant surpluses (over US$4 billion each in 2010) in its trade with Chile and Venezuela. The latter became a full member in 2012. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:85%;" |- ! Country ! [[List of countries by population|Population
