{{Orphan|date=March 2018}}
'''Real estate in Panama''' is about how the [[Republic of Panama]]'s [[real estate industry]] has grown since 2006, as foreign investments helped to fuel Panama's economy and housing market.
In spite of the economic and housing market growth, [[poverty]] is a problem in Panama. Most indigenous people live in extreme poverty while others located in rural areas live in basic poverty. Lack of sanitation, electricity, basic water, health, and education amongst the poor is a serious problem affecting Panama’s housing conditions.
In an attempt to encourage foreign investments for real estate projects and infrastructure, the government of Panama enacted laws protecting foreigners and citizens who make investments.
[[Corruption]] permeates the real estate market including claims of drug profits and money laundering financing real estate projects.
Similar to the U.S. and Canada, Panama uses a system of publicly recorded titled deeds as proof of real estate ownership. A unique Rights of Possession system exists allowing individuals to occupy unused government lands in order to make improvements to them.
==Background== The Republic of Panama is located in [[Central America]] between the [[Republic of Costa Rica]] and the [[Republic of Colombia]]. Its political structure is that of a [[Presidential system|presidential]] representative democratic republic with a [[multi-party system]].<ref>Republic of Panama's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, "Operations Manual Summit of the Americas 2015", Page 2, http://cumbredelasamericas.pa/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/manual_en.pdf</ref>
Since the [[Panama Canal]] opened in 1914, The [[Economy of Panama]] has depended on banking, transportation, and the [[service industry]].<ref>2015 Index of Economic Freedom: Panama http://www.heritage.org/index/country/panama</ref> According to a 2012 report by the [[U.S. State Department]], Panama is open to foreign investment with a generally positive investment climate and "sterling economic success" enjoying high economic growth with expected continuing "strong growth in the years ahead".<ref>U.S. State Dept., "2012 Investment Climate – Panama" June 2012, http://www.state.gov/e/eb/rls/othr/ics/2012/191215.htm</ref> [[The World Bank]] reported Panama has experienced the fastest economic growth in Latin America for the past ten years.<ref>World Bank, "Panama Overview" 2014 http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/panama/overview</ref> In spite of its growing economy, nearly 25% of Panama's population lives in poverty in 2015.<ref>CIA, "World Factbook: Panama 2015", https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pm.html</ref>
==Poverty==
The World Bank states that while Panama has experienced the fastest economic growth since 2006, indigenous children have "significantly less access to basic services such as education, electricity and sanitation than children in rural or urban areas."<ref>The World Bank, "Panama Overview" August 18, 2015 http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/panama/overview</ref> The World Bank also claims that Panama has the largest inequality of separation between the rich and the poor in the world. Poverty amongst the indigenous areas is "abysmal" where 95% are poor and 86% "live in extreme poverty". In the rural areas away from the cities 65% live in poverty and 39% live in extreme poverty.<ref>The World Bank, "Panama: Poverty Assessment: Priorities and Strategies for Poverty Reduction" 2011 http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/TOPICS/EXTPOVERTY/EXTPA/0,,contentMDK:20207841~menuPK:443285~pagePK:148956~piPK:216618~theSitePK:430367,00.html</ref>
According to the Global Brigades, an international non-profit organization dedicated to alleviating health problems and economic disparity, nearly 30% of Panama’s population lives in poverty in rural communities lacking in basic water, health, and education.<ref>Global Brigades Organization, "Panama" https://www.globalbrigades.org/panama</ref>
==Investment security==
According to Christopher Howard who has authored 15 books on retiring and investing in Latin American countries including Panama wrote: "Foreign investment is encouraged by a business oriented government".<ref>Christopher Howard, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=t-q2qccKWj4C&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=panama+safe+to+invest&source=bl&ots=w9PXUczdbI&sig=bMX6reZgo9YQm8_YYD-VH3sa_Fs&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=panama%20safe%20to%20invest&f=false The Official Guide to Living and Investing in Panama]'' Costa Rica Books, 2nd Edition 2010, Page 123, {{ISBN|9781881233466}},</ref> Professors Edward Jackiewicz and Jim Craine of California State University at Northridge claim that Panama in 2010 found a temporary niche ''as a safe place to invest''.<ref>Edward L. Jackiewicz and Jim Craine, California State University at Northridge, "Destination Panama: An Examination of the Migration-Tourism-Foreign Investment Nexus", 2010, Introduction Page, https://journal.lib.uoguelph.ca/index.php/rasaala/article/view/1498/</ref> Panama has a specific law protecting foreign investments called Law 54 of 1998. According to the Panama government, The Foreign Investor Protection Law states that foreign investors have the same rights as nationals in Panama.<ref>Panama Government Agency "PROINVEX" http://proinvex.mici.gob.pa/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=85&Itemid=91&lang=en</ref>
The U.S. State Department reported in 2013 that numerous U.S. investors complained about fraud and corruption involved with purchases of titled real properties in Panama.<ref>U.S. Department of State,"2013 Investment Climate Statement - Panama", February 2013 http://www.state.gov/e/eb/rls/othr/ics/2013/204711.htm</ref> Other possible investment risks are connected to long standing corruption, cronyism, being a zone for cocaine transshipments and [[Illegal drug trade|drug money laundering]], and high exposure to North and South American economic environments.<ref>Michigan State University, Global Edge, [http://globaledge.msu.edu/countries/panama/risk Panama Risk Assessment] 2015,</ref>
==History: 2006 - present==
Panama's real estate market began to grow in 2006.<ref>Kent Davis, "Panama Real Estate an Insider's Game?", The Visitor, May 31, 2013 https://ftp.thevisitorpanama.com/2013/05/panama-real-estate-an-insiders-game/</ref><ref>Eugene Kiselev, "The concrete Jungle: Panama's Construction Explosion", Lehigh University Press, https://martindale.cc.lehigh.edu/sites/martindale.cc.lehigh.edu/files/the_concrete_jungle.pdf</ref>
'''2006 - 2007'''
The building boom began with the proposed skyscraper project called the [[Palacio de la Bahia]] , even though it was cancelled in 2006.<ref>Skyscraper Page "Palacio de la Bahia", http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=41303</ref> A second tall skyscraper project was also proposed around the same time. The [[Ice Tower]] was to be 104 stories on the seafront Avenue Balboa in Panama City began construction in 2007, but was cancelled later that year.<ref>Emporis, "Ice Tower", http://www.emporis.com/buildings/250025/ice-tower-panama-city-panama</ref><ref>Skyscraper Page, "Ice Tower", http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=42669</ref> The media publicity regarding both of these projects generated interest in Panama real estate. "The real estate boom in Panama City started in 2006."<ref>PTY English News, http://www.ptyenglishnews.com/Panama-Real-Estate.html</ref> The failure of the [[Palacio de la Bahia]] and [[Ice Tower]] skyscraper projects generated a lot of international media publicity.<ref>Panama Guide, June 22, 2007, http://www.panama-guide.com/article.php/20070622080305821</ref>
Panama City's real estate boom really got a lift when [[Donald Trump]] announced the construction of a huge hotel, casino, condominium apartments, and office building on the waterfront in 2006.<ref>The Tico Times newspaper, "Donald Trump Launches Luxury Tower in Panama", April 28, 2006 http://www.ticotimes.net/2006/04/28/donald-trump-launches-luxury-tower-in-panama</ref> The [[Trump Ocean Club International Hotel and Tower]] was to be a $220 million development including a hotel, casino, yacht club, full-service spa and a private beach club.<ref>The New York Times, "Trump Ocean Club, International Hotel & Tower", May 5, 2006 https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/05/realestate/05break1.html?_r=0</ref> The 70 story [[Trump Ocean Club International Hotel and Tower]] building shaped like a ship's sail was to be the most expensive and largest building south of the United States with Donald Trump's name helping Panama's image worldwide.<ref>Time Magazine, "Donald Trump Goes on an Adventure in Panama", March 20, 2010, http://content.time.com/time/business/article/0,8599,1973869,00.html</ref> Donald Trump's Trump Ocean Club International Hotel and Tower began construction in 2007 and the hotel officially opened on July 6, 2011.<ref>Skyscraper Page, "Trump Ocean Club International Hotel & Tower", http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=45232</ref>
The former U.S. Howard Air Force Base was to be developed on a specialized economic zone of 1,400 hectares called the [[Panama Pacifico]] to be developed by [[London & Regional Properties]] from the [[United Kingdom]] , with an initial investment of $705 million, which included 20,000 homes, according to the government's Panama Pacific Agency (APP).<ref>Panama Pacific Agency (APP) http://www.app.gob.pa/index.php?p=app</ref>
[[Reuters]] claimed that Panama's construction boom may have been fueled by illegal drug money based on the amount of empty new condominium buildings while construction continued including 9 out of 10 of Latin America's tallest buildings.<ref>Andrew Beatty, Reuters, "Construction boom in Panama is built on drug money", December 7, 2007 https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/12/31/us-panama-skyscrapers-idUSN2053334120071231</ref>
Corruption has always been a factor effecting Panama's economy.<ref>Mauricio Cárdenas and Natalia Salazar, Inter-American Development Bank Report, "Panama's Growth Diagnostics", Page 22, September 17, 2007 http://www.iadb.org/res/files/GDM/September/PA-final.pdf</ref> In February 2007, a study published by Vanderbilt University disclosed the cost of Panama's corruption on its economy was between $600 million and $1.2 billion causing the nation's growth rate to fall 0.5% to 1% in 2006.<ref>Orlando Perez, Ph.D. and Mitchell Seligson, Ph.D., Vanderbilt University, "The Political Culture of Democracy in Panama: 2006", Page 72, February 2007 http://www.vanderbilt.edu/lapop/panama/2006-politicalculture.pdf</ref>
Despite all of the positive publicity there were some speculating a real estate bubble would burst because most Panamanians couldn't afford the high prices and not enough foreigners would purchase the expensive new apartments.<ref>Walter Molano, Latin Trade, "Panama: A Bubble Waiting to Burst" September 26, 2006 http://latintrade.com/panama-a-bubble-waiting-to-burst/</ref>
The skyscraper construction boom caused abusive conditions by developers against buyers resulting in a Third Court of Appeals of Panama decision dated November 27, 2007 whereby new rules were created to stem the abusive conditions in new construction purchase and sales contracts.<ref>Eduardo Achurra M. of Pardini law firm, HG.Org Legal Resources, May 20, 2008 "Real Estate Buyer Rights in Panama: Recent Developments" http://www.hg.org/article.asp?id=6188</ref>
Regardless of the real estate economic boom, The [[World Bank]] published a report in 2007 calling for more progress with poverty reduction in Panama.<ref>The World Bank, "Panama - Poverty assessment : toward effective poverty reduction", June 25, 2007, http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/2007/06/16274828/panama-panama-poverty-assessment-toward-effective-poverty-reduction#</ref>
'''2008'''
Spanish real estate developer, Interplus, planned US$280 million real-estate investments in two projects in Panama City's Balboa Avenue."<ref>Central America Data, May 27, 2008, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Interplus_invertira_280_millones_en_dos_proyectos_en_Ave_Balboa__ver_mas__Actualicese_con_La_Prensa_Web</ref> Spanish real estate developer, Marina d'Or, planned a US$18.6 million condominium tower in Panama in 2008.<ref>Central America Data, May 28, 2008, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Promotora_Marina_dOr_llega_a_Panama__Actualicese_con_La_Prensa_Web</ref> The $246 million investment began for The Hard Rock Hotel in Panama City in 2008.<ref>Central America Data, November 6, 2008, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/246_million_for_hotel_in_Panama</ref> Investors from the U.S., [[Colombia]], [[Europe]], and [[Mexico]] were looking to invest in construction projects.<ref>Central America Data, "Panama enjoys construction boom." July 4, 2008, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panama_enjoys_construction_boom</ref>
In 2008, Panama's poverty rate remained high in spite of the country's strong economic growth.<ref>The Rural Poverty Portal Organization, "Rural poverty in Panama", 2008 http://www.ruralpovertyportal.org/country/home/tags/panama</ref>
'''2009'''
The effects of the 2008 global economic crisis had little effect on Panama's housing market compared to other countries.<ref>Central America Data, April 2, 2009, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/The_Housing_Market_in_Panama</ref> 7,656 new [[Panama]] homes were sold from September 2008 to September 2009 with a net of $861 million USD.<ref>Central America Data, September 11, 2009, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Analysis_of_Panamas_Real_Estate_Market</ref> Every part of Panama was seeing an increase in shopping mall developments in 2009.<ref>Central America Data, September 22, 2009. http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Shopping_Mall_Fever_in_Panama</ref>
[[Venezuelans]] deposited over $1.4 billion USD into Panama banks in 2009. Venezuelan capital amounted to $2.5 billion in 2009 in Panama's Colon Free Zone.<ref>Central America Data, June 22, 2009, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Level_Venezuelan_Investment_Rises_in_Panama</ref>
According to [[The Economist]], "Panama's income distribution is among the least equal in the world."<ref>The Economist, "Panama Canal: A Plan to unlock prosperity", December 3, 2009, http://www.economist.com/node/15014282</ref>
'''2010'''
Panama's 29 banks were offering up to 98% financing for 30-year mortgages with preferential interest rates including free appraisals and commission waivers in 2010.<ref>Central America Data, March 24, 2010, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Residential_Mortgages_in_Panama</ref>
The new residential and business park complex, Panama Pacifico, was expected to invest $345 million USD in the next five years.<ref>Central America Data, August 30, 2010, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panama_Pacifico_to_Invest_345_Million_in_5_Years</ref>
Panama's real estate market grew in 2010 due to increase in tourism, having [[U.S. Dollar]] currency, growing economy, good medical care, and low cost of living. Tourism grew by 6% and it was estimated that 1.9 million would visit Panama in 2011.<ref>Encuentra24 "Panama's Real Estate Growth" 2011 http://www.encuentra24.com/content/panama-en/real-estate/view/panama-real-estate-market-growth</ref>
Panama was now experiencing a buyer's market because of a condominium over supply. According to the president of Panama's real estate association, there were up to 8,000 unsold luxury apartments while other market observers were claiming as much as 15,000 unsold apartments.<ref>Kevin Brass, World Property Journal, "Buyers Have Opportunities in Panama's Condo Market", May 19, 2010 http://www.worldpropertyjournal.com/international-markets/residential-real-estate/real-estate-news-panama-real-estate-panama-condo-sales-international-living-ronan-mcmahon-panama-real-estate-bubble-balboa-condos-for-sale-paitill-2561.php</ref>
In 2010, Panama's poverty level was 29.8% of its population.<ref>The World Bank, "Panama Data", http://data.worldbank.org/country/panama</ref>
'''2011'''
Construction of residential and non-residential properties grew by 64% in the month of April.<ref>Central America Data, August 24, 2011, http://en.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panama_Construction_Sector_Grows_by_64</ref> Panama's Superintendency of Banks (government banking watchdog) issued a study of the real estate market showing growth in the construction sector. Bank loans for commercial construction grew by 32.4% from June 2010 to June 2011.<ref>Central America Data, November 4, 2011, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panamas_Real_Estate_Market</ref>
Fifty skyscrapers had been built or were near completion since 2007 raising questions about over development in Panama City having dreams of first world hope built on third world infrastructures.<ref>BBC News, "Panama's towering ambitions strain its infrastructure", July 18, 2011 https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-14152439</ref> In spite of the growing economy and proclaimed real estate boom, many new condominium buildings were unoccupied suggesting no tenants and absentee owners with U.S. law enforcement officials believing the construction boom was based on illegal money laundering. Over building of offices created a bubble and the rural poor remained poor as the economic boom had no effect on them.<ref>The New York Times, "Bursts of Economic Growth in Panama Have Yet to Banish Old Ghosts", December 13, 2011 https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/14/world/americas/panamas-bursts-of-growth-have-yet-to-banish-old-ghosts.html</ref> The real estate boom did not help Panama's poor as approximately 1/3 lived in poverty.<ref>NPR Organization, "Panama Booms While Poor Watch From Afar", April 6, 2012, https://www.npr.org/2012/04/16/150727218/panama-booms-while-poor-watch-from-afar</ref>
'''2012'''
Panama's present and future infrastructure projects included a new rail system, new roadways, airport expansion, large-scale event venues, mega shopping malls, and thousands of new hotel rooms.<ref>Latin Trade Magazine, "Panama's Travel and Tourism Boom" 2012 http://latintrade.com/panama%e2%80%99s-travel-and-tourism-boom/</ref> Prices continued to rise in Panama's housing market with no signs of a housing bubble.<ref>Central America Data, March 21, 2012, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/No_Housing_Bubble_in_Panama</ref> A group of Panamanian companies called, Convivienda, projected $665 million in sales for 2012 delivering 7,429 new homes.<ref>Central America Data, April 19, 2012, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/House_Sales_for_665_million_in_2012</ref> During the first seven months, $918 million of approved building permits for construction projects amounted to a 45.3% increase over the same period in 2011.<ref>Central America Data, September 24, 2012, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/918_million_in_Approved_Building_Permits</ref>
President [[Ricardo Martinelli]] vetoed items contained in a law passed by the National Assembly which would have curbed abuses by the construction industry against purchasers of new construction properties. The new law intended to prevent developers from taking advantage of purchasers in regards to abandoned projects, delays in completion caused by developers, and limits on how much developers could increase contracted sales prices for increased costs of materials.<ref>Newsroom Panama, "Martinelli vetoes bill to curb developer abuses" April 14, 2012 http://www.newsroompanama.com/news/panama/martinelli-vetoes-bill-to-curb-developer-abuses</ref>
[[Colón, Panama]], the largest free zone in Latin America, was a blight of crime and poverty in spite of a booming economy where parts of the population were excluded form its economic success.<ref>BBC News, "Colon Free Zone: Panama repeals land sale law", October 28, 2012 https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-20118579</ref> Panama's economic growth in 2012 did not result in better conditions for its poor due to government policy mistakes leaving no effective policies to reduce poverty.<ref>Social Watch Organization, "Economic growth is not enough:Panama", http://www.socialwatch.org/node/14015</ref>
'''2013'''
During January 2013, Panama banks granted $2.92 billion in construction loans, which was more than $89 million than in January 2012.<ref>Central America Data, April 1, 2013, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panama_Boom_in_Construction_Loans</ref> During the first quarter of 2013 building permits rose by 60% totaling $156 million for homes and commercial buildings.<ref>Central America Data, May 6, 2014, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panama_Building_Permits_Rise_60</ref> During the first half of 2013, luxury office buildings created another construction boom for Panama.<ref>Central America Data, June 26, 2013 http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panama_Investment_Boom_in_Luxury_Offices_Continues</ref> The Panama construction sector saw an increase of 427% in construction loans over the past 3 years.<ref>Central America Data, July 16, 2013, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panama_Experiences_Construction_Loan_Boom</ref>
Foreign buyers boost Panama real property prices in anticipation of the completion of the third locks for the Panama Canal.<ref>The Financial Times, "Panama Property Boosted By Influx of Foreign Buyers" August 9, 2013, http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/27477ad4-fa90-11e2-a7aa-00144feabdc0.html</ref> During the first six months in 2013, construction projects values were $956 million which was an increase of $38 million during the same period in 2012.<ref>Central America Data, "Panama: Rise in Residential Construction" October 14, 2013 http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Panama_Rise_in_Residential_Construction</ref> New high-end luxury apartments market had surged over the past five years due to increasing purchase power by Panamanians and foreigners with income expecting higher quality housing.<ref>Kent Davis, Newsroom Panama, "What big bucks will get you in Panama" October 20, 2013 http://www.newsroompanama.com/news/panama/real-estate-3-what-big-bucks-will-get-you-in-panama</ref> Second homebuyers from Canada, the U.S., Colombia, and Venezuela were buying up a 20-mile beachfront stretch near the resort town of [[Coronado, Panama]].<ref>The New York Times, "Panama Beach Towns Prepare for a Burst of Buyers", December 20, 2013, https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/20/greathomesanddestinations/In-Panama-New-Airport-Expected-To-Spur-Home-Sales.html?ref=topics</ref>
Rental prices increased dramatically due to the increase of foreigners and multinational companies where rents in Panama City rose 40% over the past five years.<ref>Newsroom Panama, "Paradise on the cheap no more" December 8, 2013 http://www.newsroompanama.com/news/panama/paradise-on-the-cheap-no-more</ref>
In Panama City 1997 there were around 1,400 hotel rooms and in 2013 there were more than 15,000 rooms with an additional 4,500 rooms under construction. While its economy expanded over the past five years by 50%, Panama still struggled with poverty and crime.<ref>The New York Times, "Panama City Rising" May 3, 2013 https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/05/travel/panama-city-rising.html</ref> The [[BBC]] reported that while Panama had the fastest growing economy in Latin America with new buildings going skywards; the poor indigenous communities were not benefitting from the new wealth.<ref>BBC, "From Our Own Correspondent in Panama", August 15, 2013 http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01dvcyd</ref> While Panama's economy was averaging 9% growth over the past five years, it still had one of the largest disparities between the wealthy and the poor in Latin America.<ref>The New York Times, "A Once-Vibrant City Struggles as Panama Races Ahead on a Wave of Prosperity" March 23, 2013 https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/24/world/americas/frustrations-in-colon-panama-as-economic-growth-skirts-by.html?_r=0</ref>
'''2014'''
Panama's economy kept thriving as a banking and regional business hub.<ref>Jonathan Kendall, "Panama's Investment and Banking Boom", Institutional Investor 2014 http://www.institutionalinvestor.com/Article/3318322/Panamas-Investment-and-Banking-Boom.html#.ValUXrtRFjo</ref> In 2013, building permits values increased by 27% and were expected to keep the same pace in 2014 as the construction boom in Panama continued.<ref>Central America Data, January 10, 2014, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Construction_Continues_to_Boom_in_Panama_1</ref> The [[New York Times]] in its April 3, 2014 edition proclaimed: "Panama Capitalizes on Glimmers of Resurgence" <ref>The New York Times, "Panama Capitalizes on Glimmers of Resurgence" April 3, 2014 https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/04/greathomesanddestinations/panama-seizes-on-glimmers-of-real-estate-resurgence.html?_r=0</ref>
Despite apparent economic growth, office vacancies were soaring at the highest percentage in Latin America.<ref>Natasha Kracynski, ExpatNewsWire, "Despite High Growth, Panama Real Estate Bubble Bursts", December 4, 2014 http://expatnewswire.com/news/2014/12/04/despite-high-growth-panama-real-estate-bubble-bursts/</ref>
Corruption in Panama was still a major problem with the Russian mafia controlling prime real properties in Panama City. Panama was a country of contrasts with parts of Panama City compared to [[Singapore]], [[Miami]], and [[Dubai]] while others parts were similar to the slums of [[Rio de Janeiro]] and parts of the countryside experienced 90% poverty.<ref>BBC News, "Has Panama weaned itself off drugs and cleaned up?" August 3, 2014 https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-27945558</ref> The International Monetary Fund (IMF) reported that Panama had failed to reduce tax evasion, fraud, and money laundering involving the purchasing of commercial and industrial real properties, other luxury assets, and financial services.<ref>Newsroom Panama, "Panama fertile ground for fraud, tax evasion, money laundering - IMF", March 10, 2014 http://www.newsroompanama.com/news/panama/panama-fertile-ground-for-fraud-tax-evasion-money-laundering-imf</ref>
Since taking control of the Panama Canal from the U.S. in 2000 the country had seen dramatic growth with visible prosperity in Panama City, but Panama still suffered from widespread poverty.<ref>NPR Organization, "Panama's Canal Divides A Country Into Haves And Have-Nots" June 1, 2014 https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2014/05/30/317394468/panamas-canal-divides-a-country-into-haves-and-have-nots</ref> While Panama prospered over the last 10 years, the benefits were not shared by all where the country's welfare still needed to be lifted.<ref>Fox News Latino, "Panama Canal Centennial Spoiled By Specter Of Expansion Woes", August 16, 2014 http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/money/2014/08/16/panama-canal-centennial-spoiled-by-specter-expansion-woes/</ref>
'''2015'''
In 2015, international investors were said to fuel Panama City's real estate growth.<ref>PTY Life Magazine, "International Investors Fuel Panama City Real Estate Growth", March 2015, http://pty.life/panama-city-real-estate-growth/</ref> Foreign investments in Panama of $1.7 billion in the first quarter of 2015 increased by 32% over the same period in 2014 according to the National Institute of Statistics and Census.<ref>PTY Life Magazine, "International Investments in Panama Ramping Up", July 28, 2015 http://pty.life/international-investment-in-panama-is-ramping-up/</ref> Panama City's real estate market was experiencing substantial rising sales and prices. Like Miami, Panama City relied heavily on foreign investors who were finding real estate investments very attractive.<ref>Fortune Builders Real Estate Education Company, "Panama City Real Estate and Market Trends", July 20, 2015, http://www.fortunebuilders.com/panama-city-real-estate-and-market-trends/</ref> "With current and developing projects, Panama was once again proving a boom time for renters of construction equipment."<ref>Newsroom Panama, "Panama’s continuing building boom", August 19, 2015 http://www.newsroompanama.com/business/real-estate/panama’s-continuing-building-boom</ref> For the first time, Panama City’s real estate market was seeing a significant increase of European buyers, primarily from Italy, Spain and Switzerland.<ref>The Visitor, "The Europeans Are Coming", October 1, 2015 Page 2 https://thevisitorpanama.com/issues/visitor21-40/index.html</ref><ref>Jeff Barton, NuWire Investment, "Influx of Euro Buyers Hits Panama City Real Estate", September 17, 2015 http://www.nuwireinvestor.com/articles/new-influx-of-euro-buyers-hits-panama-city-real-estate-63045.aspx</ref>
Panama over built hotel rooms created a crisis in the hotel industry where as much as 70% was discounted for hotel rooms to attract customers.<ref>Newsroom Panama, "Panama Hotel Rooms A Buyer's Market", July 20, 2015 http://www.newsroompanama.com/travel/panama/panama-hotel-rooms-a-buyer-s-market</ref>
A Bill before Panama's National Assembly in 2015 sought to tighten money laundering controls as the country remained on the gray list of the [[Financial Action Task Force]](FATF)which negatively effected the nation's economy. A recent International Monetary Fund report indicated that gaps existed in money laundering controls involving real estate agents, insurance brokers, casinos, and lawyers transactions.<ref>Newsroom Panama, "Realtors, casinos, lawyers, insurance, face money laundering controls", February 2, 2015 http://www.newsroompanama.com/news/latin-america/realtors,-casinos,-lawyers,-insurance,-face-money-laundering-controls</ref>
Panama needed to get rid of its reputation as a major transit for illegal immigrants and illegal drugs and a money laundering haven while 33% of its population lived in poverty.<ref>BBC News, "Panama Profile" February 13, 2015 https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-19888936</ref> Panama was still a poverty stricken country.<ref>DW Media Broadcast, "Poverty in Panama" April 10, 2015 http://www.dw.com/en/poverty-in-panama/av-18374058</ref> Panama continued to have the highest economic growth rate in the American continent while the Ministry of Finance announced a reduction in the poverty rate over the past year on October 8, yet over 10 percent of the population remains in “extreme poverty”.<ref>Newsroom Panama,"Rate down but over 10% of Panamanians in extreme poverty" October 10, 2015 http://www.newsroompanama.com/news/panama/rate-down-but-over-10-of-panamanians-in-extreme-poverty</ref> In spite of the housing boom, construction of luxury apartments made the dream of owning a home further away for the majority of citizens.<ref>Newsroom Panama, "Martinelli’s Singapore fantasy clouded by corruption" August 9, 2015 http://www.newsroompanama.com/columns/your-man/martinelli’s-singapore-fantasy-clouded-by-corruption</ref> Panama's Vice-President and the Cabinet Council proposed that the National Assembly pass a new law specifically for the extradition of Russian fugitives.<ref>Newsroom Panama, "Cabinet approval for Russia extradition deal" August 31, 2015 http://www.newsroompanama.com/news/panama/cabinet-approval-for-russia-extradition-deal</ref>
== Real estate ownership ==
'''Titled properties'''
There are two types of real property ownership. One is the traditional titled deed ownership seen in most countries. The second is called "Rights of Possession" which is the right to occupy government owned properties with the ability to transfer the rights to others.<ref>Panama Offshore Legal Services, "Real Estate Basics (Part 1)", The Visitor, April 22, 2011 https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor17-16/third.html</ref>
Similar to "fee simple" title in the U.S., Panama titled property is the most secure method of owning real estate. Title deeds filed with the government's Public Registry verify one's title allowing banks to issue [[mortgage]] loans using the property as [[collateral (finance)]].<ref>Steven Rich, "Know what type of Real Estate you are buying", The Visitor, September 22, 2006 https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor12-20/special_visitor.html</ref>
'''Public registry'''
Ownership of private property transfers when the title deed is registered with Panama's Public Registry.<ref>Panama attorneys Patricia Villanueva and Elizabeth Heurtematte in Latin Lawyer November 2014 http://latinlawyer.com/reference/topics/67/jurisdictions/34/panama/</ref> Liens, mortgages and other security instruments are registered in Panama's Public Registry with online access to most of this information.<ref>U.S. State Dept., "2012 Investment Climate – Panama", June 2012, http://www.state.gov/e/eb/rls/othr/ics/2012/191215.htm</ref> The link to Panama's Public Registry is: http://www.registro-publico.gob.pa/
'''Rights of possession'''
People can take possession of government land to improve it. This is called "Rights of Possession" that can be passed down to the next generation and to the next. These rights can be sold to other parties including foreigners.<ref>Panama Offshore Legal Services, "About Rights of Possession Properties" Part 1, The Visitor, April 29, 2011 https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor17-17/third.html</ref>
'''Concession properties'''
[[Concession (contract)]] properties are government grants to public property allowing individuals or companies to occupy for a specific purpose such as developing a [[marina]] or a [[hotel]]. Most concessions are for 20 years and may be renewed. Concessions are popular in coastal areas and government protected lands. The government protects the concession rights through a written [[contract]]. [[Title insurance]] is available for concession properties.<ref>Panama Offshore Legal Services, "About Rights of Possession Properties" Part 2, The Visitor, May 6, 2011 https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor17-18/third.html</ref> In 2015, a new law was created allowing for marine concession rights to be used by investors as collateral for loans.<ref>Panama attorneys Diego de la Guardia and Jose Luis Sosa, "Panama", Latin Lawyer, July 31, 2015 http://latinlawyer.com/reference/topics/53/jurisdictions/34/panama/</ref>
'''Real estate trusts'''
In 2010, Panama created a new law allowing for Real Estate Trusts, which are based on the U.S. [[Real estate investment trust]] (REIT) and made changes to the tax laws in 2014 allowing investors to avoid paying a [[Capital Gains Tax]] while the Trust only pays a 5% Dividends Tax. Small investors can join other investors in forming a Real Estate Trust to purchase real estate to develop and lease.<ref>The Wall Street Journal, "Panama REIT Industry Aims for Takeoff" December 2, 2014</ref>
'''Real estate taxes'''
Panama has a [[Property Tax]] based on the value of the land and its improvements with the maximum annual rate being 2.1% of the total value. Prior to 2012, Panama had several laws exempting certain residential real properties from paying the property tax for 20 years. Starting in 2012, the property tax exemption changed to 15 years for residential properties valued up to $100,000 USD; 10 years for properties valued from $100,000 to $250,000; and a 5-year exemption for properties valued above $250,000. Non-residential and commercial properties enjoy a 10-year exemption.<ref>Encuentra 24, 2014, http://www.encuentra24.com/content/panama-en/real-estate/view/a-review-of-annual-panama-property-taxs</ref>
Panama also has a Title Transfer Tax of 2% of the actual value of the real property imposed when the seller transfers the title to the buyer. There is also a 10% Capital Gains Tax which can be reduced to 5% if owned by a corporation selling its corporate shares instead of title to the property which also avoids the 2% Title Transfer Tax.<ref>Manoj Chatlani, Panama attorney & Steven Rich, The Visitor, "Tips for Buying Panama Real Estate", January 28, 2008, https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor14-3/special_visitor.html</ref>
Rental [[income taxes]] for property owners is exempt for the first $30,000 USD and has a 27% rate on income above that amount. The Capital Gains Tax differs for individuals who only pay a 10% rate while real estate dealers (individuals selling multiple properties per tax year) pay up to 27% and corporations pay a flat 30% rate.<ref>Steven Rich, "Panama's Taxes Related to Real Estate", Panama Guide, August 7, 2006, http://www.panama-guide.com/article.php/20060807175536720</ref>
'''Condominiums'''
Panama has a Horizontal Property Law for condominiums. This law governs [[condominium]] units as well as a condominium building's common areas like the pool, lobby, gym, and social areas. Panama's Public Registry has the Horizontal Property Regime Section where all important documents are recorded such as the land's title deed and the condominium's rules & regulations.<ref>Panama attorneys Patricia Villanueva and Elizabeth Heurtematte, "Panama", Latin Lawyer November 2014 http://latinlawyer.com/reference/topics/67/jurisdictions/34/panama/</ref>
There are Panama laws protecting real property buyers. Law 6 of 2006 prohibits the construction industry from engaging in advertising fraud. In 2007, Panama's Ministry of Housing enacted regulations preventing real estate developers and their promoters from selling or advertising properties before the approval of the project's Master Plan. Panama's National Environmental Authority also has regulations over real estate developments. Panama real estate buyers also are protected by Law 45 of 2007 known as the Consumer Protection Act allowing the Consumer Protection Agency to investigate buyer's complaints against real estate developers and agents.<ref>Panama Offshore Legal Services, "Pre-Construction Contracts", The Visitor, June 25, 2010, https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor16-26/third.html</ref>
'''Condominium hotels'''
[[Condo]] Hotels are popular in Panama especially in Panama City and along the beaches of both coasts. Investors purchase an apartment in either the hotel building or an adjoining apartment building. The developer of the hotel will manage the advertising, renting, and cleaning of the apartment and will share the income with the investor. Users of the apartments will have access to the pool, gym, spa, tennis courts, restaurants, and other hotel amenities.<ref>Steven Rich, "Condo Hotel Investment", The Visitor, October 10, 2008, http://demo.vitocortesewebsite.dev3.sibers.com/New_Site/Visitor14-37/special_visitor.html</ref>
'''Real estate brokers'''
'''Definition'''
Panama law defines a [[real estate broker]] as one who professionally and habitually operates as an agent, intermediary, mediator, or representative in real estate transactions. The law excludes people who work as administrators, promoters, maintenance providers, and rent collectors working for a licensed real estate broker. Because of these exceptions, many foreigners work as promoters for Panama real estate companies.<ref>Steven Rich, "Finding a Real Estate Agent (Part 1)", The Visitor, May 4, 2007, https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor13-10/special_visitor.html</ref>
'''Licensing'''
A Panama [[real estate agent]] (broker) license is only available to a Panama citizen or a foreign resident (of at least five years) who must take required courses and pass a written examination administered by the Ministry of Industry & Commerce; obtain a $10,000 bond covering malpractice claims; pay a $25 annual fee; obtain a police record showing no felonies were committed; and obtain a [[Power of Attorney]].<ref>Panama Guide, "Law Governing Real Estate Agents in Panama", March 3, 2007 http://www.panama-guide.com/article.php/20070303100422247</ref>
'''Realtors in Panama'''
In order to become a "[[Realtor]]" a licensed real estate broker must be a member of the Panamanian Association of Real Estate Brokers and Developers (ACOBIR) and then apply to be a member of the [[National Association of Realtors]] (NAR).<ref>Steven Rich, "Finding a Real Estate Agent (Part 2)", The Visitor, May 18, 2007, https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor13-11/special_visitor.html</ref>
'''Law governing real estate brokers in English'''
Here is a link to the translation from Spanish to English of The Law Governing Real Estate Agents in Panama: http://www.panama-guide.com/article.php/20070303100422247
'''Multiple listing service in Panama'''
Not until 2014 did Panama start its first [[Multiple Listing Service]] (MLS) for real estate offices and agents to share their listings with each other and to have a system for sharing a [[commission (remuneration)]] when sales occur. The MLS was created by the Panama Association of Brokers and Real Estate Developers (ACOBIR) in existence since 1973.<ref>Panama English News, "Panama's First Multiple Listing Service", June 15, 2015, http://www.panamaenglishnews.com/xmultiple.html</ref>
'''Mortgages'''
Panama banks offer a real estate [[mortgage]] to its citizens and foreigners. Foreigners will pay a higher interest rate and can obtain up to 75% financing and can qualify if they have good credit.<ref>Encuentra 24, "Steps to Obtaining a Mortgage in Panama", 2014, http://www.encuentra24.com/content/panama-en/real-estate/view/steps-to-obtaining-a-mortgage-in-panama</ref>
'''Escrow companies'''
Panama has a few [[escrow]] companies, which will collect the buyer's payments and hold them until the seller transfers the property's title to the buyer. The escrow company will perform a [[title search]] to make sure no [[liens]] or [[encumbrances]] exist, verify that the seller is the true owner, and will pay the real estate commission and other costs spelled out in the Buy-Sell Contract.<ref>Panama Offshore Legal Services, "Escrow Services", The Visitor, April 1, 2010, https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor16-14/third.html</ref>
'''Title insurance'''
The first [[title insurance]] company in Panama was Chicago Title Insurance Company from the U.S.<ref>Central America Data, May 29, 2009, http://www.centralamericadata.com/en/article/home/Latin_America_Title_Opens_in_Panama</ref> Title insurance is available in Panama to protect buyers from liens, encumbrances, and defects to the title.<ref>Steven Rich, "Title Insurance", The Visitor, April 10, 2009, https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor15-15/special_visitor.html</ref>
'''Developing real estate'''
Panama's urban areas are divided by [[zoning]] codes setting forth the type of construction, area and height restrictions, density, allowable activities, and parking spaces. Areas are divided into commercial, residential, or mixed usage. These codes must be followed in order for a [[real estate development]] or a builder to obtain a [[construction permit]] and an [[occupancy permit]].<ref>Panama attorneys Patricia Villanueva and Elizabeth Heurtematte, "Panama", Latin Lawyer, November 2014 http://latinlawyer.com/reference/topics/67/jurisdictions/34/panama/</ref> A builder needs to obtain approval from eight government agencies in order to begin construction of real property in Panama.<ref>Steven Rich, "Developing Properties", The Visitor, January 26, 2007, https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor13-3/special_visitor.html</ref>
'''Renting properties'''
Real estate [[leases]] are governed by the Civil Code of 1917, which covers most residential leases and all commercial and industrial leases. The [[security deposit]] for a residential rental is deposited with the Ministry of Housing along with the [[rental agreement]] and the security deposit is returned to the tenant after the lease expires unless the [[property owner]] claims [[property damage]] or past due rent payments. The tenant can terminate the lease before it expires with at least 30 days written notice before the next rent payment. Property owners cannot terminate leases early.<ref>Steven Rich, "Know the Rules of Renting", The Visitor, March 21, 2008, https://www.thevisitorpanama.com/New_Site/Visitor14-8/special_visitor.html</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Economy of Panama]] [[Category:Real estate by country|Panama]]

revision.text:
[[Image:SSNNavigation.jpg|thumb|[[Bone segment navigation|Surgical navigation]] for the orbit and [[Zygomatic bone|zygoma]] on the SSN system (Color coding for the preoperative, predicted and goal position of the fragments, respectively)]] The '''surgical segment navigator (SSN)''' is a computer-based system for use in [[surgical navigation]]. It is integrated into a common [[platform (computing)|platform]], together with the surgical tool navigator (STN), the surgical microscope navigator (SMN) and the 6[[degrees of freedom (engineering)|DOF]] manipulator (MKM), developed by [[Carl Zeiss AG|Carl Zeiss]].
== SSN == The '''SSN''' has been developed as a computer system for [[bone segment navigation]] in [[oral and maxillofacial surgery]]. It allows a very precise repositioning of bone fragments, with the advent of preoperative simulation and [[surgical planning]].The system has been developed since 1997 at the [[University of Regensburg|University of Regensburg, Germany]], with the support of the [[Carl Zeiss AG|Carl Zeiss Company]]. Its principle is based on an infrared localisation system, composed of an [[infrared]] camera and at least three infrared [[transmitters]] attached to each bony fragment. The SSN is mainly used in [[orthognatic surgery]] (surgical correction of dysgnathia), but also for the surgical reconstruction of the orbit, or other surgical interventions to the midface.
== SSN++ == Since 2001, at the [[University of Heidelberg|University of Heidelberg, Germany]], the '''SSN++''' has been developed, a markerless-[[patient registration|registration]] navigation system, based on a native (=markerless) [[computed tomography|CT]] or [[MRI]]. In this case, the [[patient registration]] is obtained on the operating table, using a surface scanner. The SSN++ correlates the surface scan data (gathered on the operating table) with the skin surface reconstruction from the [[dataset]] obtained preoperatively by [[computed tomography|CT]] or [[MRI]]. This principle complies with the [[TERCOM|terrain contour matching]] principle described for flying objects. The advantage of the new method is that the [[patient registration|registration of the patient's position]] becomes a simple automated procedure; on the other hand, the radiation load for the patient is reduced, compared to the method using markers.
== References == * Marmulla R, Niederdellmann H: ''Computer-assisted Bone Segment Navigation'', J Craniomaxillofac Surg 26: 347–359, 1998 * Marmulla R, Niederdellmann H: ''Surgical Planning of Computer Assisted Repositioning Osteotomies'', Plast Reconstr Surg 104 (4): 938–944, 1999 * Marmulla R, Mühling J, Lüth T, Eggers G, Hassfeld S: ''Advanced surface-recording techniques for computer-assisted oral and maxillofacial surgery'', Br J Oral Maxillofac Surg, 42: 511–519, 2004
== External links == * [http://marmulla.com/compengl.htm SSN Homepage]
[[Category:Oral and maxillofacial surgery]] [[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Computer-assisted surgery]] [[Category:Medical software]]

{{orphan|date=August 2010}} {{notability|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Sôvä nad Sŕním | native_name = | other_name = Sova nad Srním | settlement_type = Village | image_skyline = | image_caption = | image_flag = | image_shield = | motto = | nickname = | etymology = | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = Slovakia | subdivision_type1 = | subdivision_name1 = | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name2 = | subdivision_type3 = | subdivision_name3 = | subdivision_type4 = | subdivision_name4 = | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_relief = | pushpin_map_caption = | coordinates = | coordinates_footnotes = | established_title = First mentioned | established_date = 2/7/2008 | area_footnotes = | area_total_km2 = | area_total_sq_mi = | area_land_sq_mi = | area_water_sq_mi = | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = | elevation_ft = | population_as_of = 2009 | population_footnotes = | population_total = 42 | population_density_km2 = auto | population_density_sq_mi= | population_demonym = | timezone1 = [[Central European Time|CET]] | utc_offset1 = +1 | timezone1_DST = [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] | utc_offset1_DST = +2 | postal_code_type = | postal_code = | area_code_type = | area_code = | geocode = | iso_code = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Sôvä nad Sŕním''' is the name of a fictional village in [[Slovakia]]. It was founded on [[Festival fantazie]] 2008 in [[Chotěboř]] on 2 July 2008. This village is the base of Slovak [[Torchwood]][http://torchwood.cz Czech Torchwood site] branch. It is told that Torchwood 4 disappeared and reappeared on 3 places [[Prague]], [[Brno]] and Sôvä nad Sŕním.
Officially, Sôvä nad Sŕním has 42 citizens, however the number moves up to 47 during the time of mating.
The name of this village could be translated as "''Owl-nestling over Roe-point''". In Judoon language ''Sou Vou Dou Rou''. {{fict-location-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sova Nad Srnim}} [[Category:Fictional populated places in Slovakia]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=December 2016}} {{Unreferenced|date=March 2010}} }}
{{Infobox company | name = Terralink International | logo = Terralink.jpg | caption = | type = Private | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = | founder = | defunct = | location_city = Wellington | location_country = New Zealand | key_people = Mike Donald, Managing Director | industry = Geospatial Data | products = Land and Property Information | services = Spatial Data Services, Geospatial Solutions | website = {{URL|www.terralink.co.nz}} | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 75 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = www.terralink.co.nz | footnotes = }}
'''Terralink International''' was a New Zealand owned and operated provider of [[geographic information systems]] (GIS) and mapping solutions. In 2014 it was bought by Property IQ, and has now become CoreLogic NZ Limited; 60% owned by the US-based [[CoreLogic]] corporation.<ref name="Harris">{{cite news|last1=Harris|first1=Catherine|title=Property information firms merge|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/9467548/Property-information-firms-merge|accessdate=12 April 2018|work=The Nelson Mail|publisher=[[Stuff Limited]]|date=3 December 2013}}</ref>
== Overview ==
'''Terralink International''' specialises in delivering [[Cartography|mapping]], property information and imagery, as well as geographical and spatial information. Terralink also produces and updates many of New Zealand's official [[topographic]], city and scientific maps. Other [[geospatial]] related services and solutions provided by Terralink International include: * GIS/Spatial data maintenance, production and analysis * [[Photogrammetry]] * [[Cartography]] * Imagery acquisition, provision and hosting * Data replication and integration * GIS infrastructure development * Addressing Services/Matching * [[Geocoding]] * [[Online hosting]] * Web and software development * Customer Support Services * Data analytics
== History == A former [[Government-owned enterprise]] with a history extending back over 100 years, Terralink International maintains and manages New Zealand’s largest and most comprehensive land and property information database. Terralink NZ Limited was privatised in June 2001 when it was purchased by a consortium of investors to form Terralink International Limited. This occurred following a receivership in January 2001, after which its ownership was 80% Animation Research Holdings Ltd, a New Zealand company specialising in 3D animation, and 20% Spatial Holdings Ltd.
In 2014 it was bought by Property IQ, and has now become [[CoreLogic NZ Limited]]; 60% owned by the US-based [[CoreLogic]] corporation.<ref name="Harris"/> Property information firms mergeTerralink International is 100% New Zealand owned and operated.
== Location == Terralink International's head office and core production facility is situated in [[Wellington]] with a satellite office in [[Auckland]]. Currently around 75 staff are employed by Terralink International.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.terralink.co.nz Terralink International's corporate website]
[[Category:Geographic information systems]] [[Category:Companies of New Zealand]]

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} {{underlinked|date=October 2012}} {{More citations needed|date=August 2018}} }} [[File:WFink in 2007 5.jpg|thumb|250px|right|<center>'''Tier-Scalable Reconnaissance:</center>'''Three-tiered utilization on Mars. Tier 1: spaceborne orbiter; Tier 2: airborne blimps; Tier 3: ground-based rovers.]]
'''Tier-Scalable Reconnaissance''' is the term for an approach to deploying and controlling vehicles in multiple areas of interest, such as in the exploration of planets or diverse regions on Earth. It is not a rigid or fixed paradigm, but is infinitely extensible. It uses hierarchical levels of oversight called ''tiers'', each tier commanding or controlling the vehicles within the tier beneath it. The size of each tier can be scaled from one to many vehicles.
== Origination == The tier-scalable reconnaissance paradigm was originated by Dr. [[Wolfgang Fink]] et al.<ref>Fink W, Dohm JM, Tarbell MA, Hare TM, Baker VR (2005) ''Next-Generation Robotic Planetary Reconnaissance Missions: A Paradigm Shift; Planetary and Space Science'', 53, 1419-1426</ref> at the [[California Institute of Technology]].
== History == Robotic planetary exploration missions typically use a single lander or rover. This is by design, driven primarily by safety and engineering constraints, at the expense of mission reliability and science return. Rovers are generally capable mobile platforms, but they are incapable of exploring multiple distant sites on a planetary surface. They are usually not used to explore potentially hazardous, scientifically interesting regions. At the other extreme, orbiting satellites have the benefit of a global perspective, but miss much surface detailed information. In either case, using a rover or orbiter, monitoring changing events on the surface is difficult, if not altogether impossible.
Tier-scalable reconnaissance, on the other hand, distributes the burden of data gathering across different logical tiers. In this way, a mission is more distributed, goal-driven, and less constrained. And, because of the numerous vehicles in each tier, a mission is more survivable and more capable. Consider the following scenario: The vehicles in the spaceborne and airborne tiers have overhead perspectives at different scales and resolutions. They map out areas of interest and acquire terrain data, and then choose targets for visiting and sampling by the ground vehicles. The overhead perspective also allows the higher tiers to determine paths for safe passage of these vehicles to their targets. The ground-tier vehicles gather local data that complement the remote sensing data obtained by the spaceborne and airborne vehicles.
In addition to the spaceborne and ground tiers, there may be several airborne tiers having vehicles such as balloons, blimps, and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) at different altitudes. The tier-scalable reconnaissance paradigm is not limited to space, aerial, and ground applications but can be applied as well to water, subterranean, and ocean floor scenarios for scientific, commercial, or military purposes.
The tier-scalable reconnaissance paradigm is also highly automated. Spaceborne orbiters command and control the airborne vehicles autonomously, and the airborne vehicles in turn command and control the ground-tier reconnaissance vehicles. This allows orbiters, airships, and rovers to act in a unified, controlled manner. A mission that uses this paradigm is also considered more survivable. Since the airborne and ground-tier vehicles can be quite inexpensive, even expendable, many such vehicles can be used collectively to explore numerous science targets with complementary suites of instruments. Even if one or more vehicles should fail, others are present to take up the slack and continue the mission.
== Scenarios == Tier-scalable reconnaissance missions allow access to targets of great interest on planetary bodies, something which is not currently feasible with conventional single-rover or single-orbiter mission designs. Tier-scalable reconnaissance missions also enable spanning larger surface areas than previously possible – mimicking the way geologists explore regions on Earth – and therefore allow for greater data return.
Consider how the tier-scalable paradigm adapts to various environmental scenarios:
[[File:WFink in 2007 2.jpg|left|100px|border]] * '''Environments with atmospheres and with non-extreme surface temperatures (Earth, Mars):''' ** Tier 1: Spaceborne orbiters, which guide deployment and control of ** Tier 2: Airborne balloons or blimps, which in turn deploy and control ** Tier 3: Surface-based buoys, and sensors, which in turn deploy and control ** Tier 4: Submersibles and sensors.
[[File:WFink in 2007 3.jpg|left|100px|border]] * '''Environments with atmospheres and with extreme surface temperatures (Venus, Titan)''':<ref>Noor AK, Cutts JA, Balint TS (2007) ''Platforms for discovery: Exploring Titan and Venus''; Aerospace America/June 2007</ref> ** Tier 1: Spaceborne orbiters, which guide deployment and control of ** Tier 2: Airborne balloons or blimps, which, if conditions permit, deploy and control ** Tier 3: Ground sensor webs, rovers, or submersibles.
[[File:WFink in 2007 4.jpg|left|100px|border]] * '''Environments without atmospheres and with extreme surface conditions (Mercury, Moon, Europa):''' ** Tier 1: Spaceborne orbiters, which guide deployment of and communicate with ** Tier 2: Ground-based rovers and sensor webs.
== Commanding & Operation == Using traditional means, simultaneous commanding of even a few reconnaissance vehicles becomes exceedingly complex, and so the logistical and computational demands of the tier-scalable paradigm scale quickly beyond the computers able to fit on such vehicles. This problem is overcome by using a ''round-robin concurrent commanding scheme''.<ref>Fink W, Tarbell MA, Jobling FM (2008) ''Tier-Scalable Reconnaissance - A Paradigm Shift in Autonomous Remote Planetary Exploration of Mars and Beyond''. Chapter 1 in “Planet Mars Research Focus”, Ed. F. Columbus. Nova Science Publishers, Hauppauge, NY. (in press)</ref> In this scheme, the vehicles are not commanded simultaneously; instead, each is commanded in turn, one by one. Moreover, each vehicle is given a small command set to execute. In this way, one vehicle is being commanded while the others are executing their issued commands. Depending on how close the vehicles are to each other and how accurately they execute their navigation commands, an airborne deployment reassessment is done so that refined trajectories are computed for each vehicle. Thus, each vehicle can be commanded in turn without threat of collision.
In the tier-scalable paradigm, ground-tier vehicles are commanded typically through the use of local airborne vehicles, such as blimps or balloons. The airborne vehicles contain onboard tracking and command systems for use with the ground-tier vehicles. With a wide field of view, the tracking and commanding systems on board the airborne vehicles determine optimal paths for the ground-tier vehicles, identifying both obstacles and interesting science targets. The ground-tier vehicles are then commanded to navigate through the operational area to the designated targets, while avoiding the identified obstacles. Therefore, this approach does not rely on the limited horizontal view of the ground-tier vehicles. Each ground-tier vehicle includes its own instrument suite to collect information, which is transmitted back to the airborne tier.
The ground-tier vehicles may conduct measurements en route to their targets. If an interesting object is encountered along the way, a vehicle may request permission of the commanding tier to explore it. A ground-tier vehicle may also find itself in an area of geography through which it cannot pass. In this case, it would request an alternate trajectory to its target, or even a target reassignment. These resolutions are possible because the higher-level airborne commanding tier is able to reassess the deployment of the vehicles, refining the trajectories of each of the vehicles at each step. In this way, even if a vehicle should go off-course, such as from sliding on sandy soil, the commanding tier will recalculate a path to the target based on the vehicle’s current position.
== Applications == Robotic reconnaissance operations are called for in extreme environments such as space, as well as in potentially hazardous or inaccessible operational areas on Earth, such as those related to military or terrorist activities, or areas that have been exposed to biochemical agents, radiation, or natural disasters.
Tier-scalable reconnaissance opens access to geologic sites not currently feasible to visit, such as canyons, mountain ranges, chaotic and rugged terrain, impact basins and craters, even volcanoes and liquid pools or lakes. In addition, other exotic locales of scientific interest exist on the planetary bodies of the [[Solar System]] that are particularly crucial in the search for extraterrestrial biological activity in general, and sample return missions in particular.
Potential terrestrial applications include Homeland Security, border control, battlefield surveillance and reconnaissance, telecommunications relay, and weather observations, as well as monitoring of military checkpoints, standoff detection, and delivery/removal of explosives such as landmine cleanup.
== Advantages & Implications == Some of the major advantages of tier-scalable reconnaissance architectures include: # Overhead navigation, enabling deployment of simple, inexpensive, expendable ground vehicles; # Efficient commanding of multiple ground vehicles; # Mission safety, reliability, and survivability; # Optimized target identification, path planning, and obstacle avoidance; and # Real time reconnaissance, allowing identification and characterization of active events.
Also, tier-scalable reconnaissance reduces driving requirements for ground vehicles, since they already are deployed in the vicinity of where they need to be. Therefore, driving is limited to “fine-tuning” the location of the ground-tier vehicles to perform local sampling, as opposed to “long-distance” driving towards the location where they need to be. Hence, inexpensive, expendable miniaturized vehicles with limited driving capabilities can be used.
The ground-tier vehicles have limited onboard computing capabilities, since they off-load data analysis to a primary lander or higher tiers that have higher-grade computing equipment. Conceptually, a primary lander is a higher-grade computing engine that also acts as a communication relay, much like a planetary internet router between the tiers. Thus, the tier-scalable reconnaissance paradigm, by its inherent architecture, is an extended distributed computing topology unto itself.
== Developments == Individual components of the tier-scalable reconnaissance paradigm are either under development or have already been tested and proven “in the field.” These include orbiters, balloons, blimps, airships, and ground-based vehicles such as rovers and landers as well as sensor webs. The biggest challenge, however, appears to be not so much the hardware but the “intelligent” software that would enable all the components of a tier scalable mission to be integrated and function autonomously.<ref>Popular Science Magazine, March 2006 issue: ''Exploring Mars with Blimps and Cliff-scaling Robots''</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Remote sensing]]
